slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The number of connections has exceeded the high watermark threshold. Affected NodeID is <number>, with Local SPC <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The number of SCCP connections has reached the high watermark. For ITU and TTC standards, the SPC value is printed in the format: 0-16383 and 0-65535 respectively. For ANSI and China standards, the SPC value is printed in the format: 0-16777215 ([0-255]-[0-255]-[0-255]).

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the number of connections has exceeded the configured threshold value for the high watermark. If several SS7 back ends are affected, individual alarms are raised for each affected SS7 back end and the alarms are then cleared separately.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If the application cannot handle more connections, congestion occurs and end user subscribers are affected. Otherwise, the maximum number of connections is reached.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check the value of the NumberOfConnections parameter and increase the value if necessary. It is an indication of an overloaded SGSN-MME if the threshold value for the high watermark (value of the UpperConnectionThreshold parameter) is within the allowed range, but the application cannot handle more connections. In such a case, move one or more RNCs to a less loaded SGSN-MME. The ss7SccpConnHighWatermark alarm is cleared when the number of the existing connections becomes less than the threshold value for the low watermark, that is the value of the LowerConnectionThreshold parameter. To avoid generating and clearing ss7SccpConnHighWatermark alarm too many times, decrease the value of the LowerConnectionThreshold parameter.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: ss7SccpConnHighWatermark alarm is cleared when the number of the existing connections becomes less than the threshold value for the low watermark, that is, the value of the LowerConnectionThreshold parameter. To avoid generating and clearing ss7SccpConnHighWatermark too many times, decrease the value of the LowerConnectionThreshold parameter.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGSN-MME has lost the connection on the GTPv2-C path towards SGW = (<AP name>) <SGSN-MME VIP address>:<SGSN-MME Port number><-><SGW node address>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The gtpSGWPathFailure alarm is generated when a GTPv2-C path between the SGSN-MME and SGW is down.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the SGW does not respond to a GTPv2-C Echo Request message after retransmissions. This can be caused by a node restart or a GTPv2-C path failure.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Communication is not possible between the SGSN-MME and the node that caused the alarm. #Note: There are no consequences for existing PDP bearers resulting from the path failure. New requests can still be sent for new and existing PDP bearers, but are likely to be unsuccessful, since there is a problem with the path.Note#

slot.name: action
slot.value: See Interface Problem in #Troubleshooting# for further information on how to investigate the reason for the failure.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the node responds to a GTPv2-C Echo Request message.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Passive NCB has failed or is restarting and no redundant NCB is currently available.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The dpePassiveNCBFailure alarm indicates that the passive NCB is unavailable and that no redundant NCB is available. This alarm is generated by the active NCB. The cause for this alarm can be hardware- or software-related. #Note:The alarm is always generated when a SC activation is done.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The passive NCB is not in operation.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Failover is not possible, no redundancy.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Investigate passive NCB. Make sure that the passive NCB has not been blocked because of a maintenance reason.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Passive NCB is up and running. If the alarm is not cleared when backup_ncb is reported from NCL in isp.log, then manually clear the alarm.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The nocHardwareLoss alarm is generated when an AP or a DP has been reported unavailable and will be taken out of service. The cause is either a hardware or software fault.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated when an AP or DP has been reported unavailable.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The consequence depends on the role of the PIU or VM. See related alarms and events for further information on the consequences. The SGSN-MME may not operate with full capacity and it may have lost redundancy.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The trigger of the alarm can be hardware or software related. See PIU or VM Failure in #Troubleshooting# for further information on how to investigate the reason for the alarm.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The nocHardwareLoss alarm is generated when an AP or DP had been reported unavailable and will be taken out of service. The cause is either a hardware or a software fault.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Alarm Indication Signal (AIS) is detected on PCM trunk <Trunk>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: AIS failure. This alarm indicates persistent AIS failure, i.e. no framing signal is detected. RAI alarm is sent to the remote side.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the E1/T1 interface detects a cable break on the Rx side.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No traffic is received on the interface

slot.name: action
slot.value: Perform visual check of interface cable and check remote peer configuration

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: A PIU or VM has been permanently blocked (EquipmentID=<EquipmentID>).

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a PIU or VM does not start successfully after a number of attempts, either due to hardware problems or due to software faults.;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The consequence depends on the role of the PIU or VM. See related alarms and events for further information on the consequences. The SGSN-MME may not operate with full capacity and it may have lost redundancy. If too many PIUs or VMs are blocked, the SGSN-MME will enter failsafe state. For more information, see #nocNodeOutOfService#.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The trigger of the failure can be hardware or software related. See PIU or VM Failure in #Troubleshooting# for further information on how to investigate the reason for the failure.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the operator manually deblocks the equipment.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Cell Trace Mapping output buffer overflow has occurred on <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The cellTraceStreamBufferOverflow alarm is generated when the PDU output buffer of Cell Trace Mapping has reached its maximum size limit of 600000 cell traces on one AP. This occurs if the external system is unavailable or busy.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the output buffer has reached its maximum size limit. The reasons for this may be either, or both, of the following: *Busy external system;*Unavailable external system, that is, a communication error;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Cell Trace Mapping events stored in the output buffer on the AP are lost. If the Cell Trace Mapping events are configured to be logged to file, as well as being streamed, the stored log files can be fetched manually by using SFTP.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If the alarm is generated due to unavailable external server, follow the actions to be taken in the alarm #cellTraceCommunicationFailure#, in order to solve the communication failure. Another alarm has already been sent about the communication failure.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The output buffer usage has decreased below its hysteresis value for alarm clearance.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The scheduled backup creation for the <managerId> backup <backupName> failed due to the following reason: <reason>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is raised if the scheduled backup is interrupted from starting or completing. The reason for the failure needs to be investigated. When the AdminState parameter of the BrmBackupScheduler is set to LOCKED, the alarm is cleared. The next successful scheduled backup will clear the alarm. This alarm is available for all backup types.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: Future backups could fail if the causes of failure remain unsolved.

slot.name: action
slot.value: For backup manager system_local, check using the CLI command #get_brm_backup_housekeeping# if the AutoDelete parameter is set to its default value ENABLED. If it is set to DISABLED, the scheduled backup cannot be created if a manually created backup exists on local storage. If possible, correct any problems described as reasons in the alarm text and verify that the next scheduled backup succeeds and clears the alarm. If the alarm is raised because of insufficient disk space, follow the instructions for clearing the alarm #hwDiskSpaceUsageExceeded#. If the alarm is raised because of an internal error, more information about the cause of the backup failure can be found in the output of the #fsbBackupFailure# alarm.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: When the AdminState parameter of the BrmBackupScheduler is set to LOCKED, the alarm is cleared. The next successful scheduled backup will clear the alarm.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The number of TCAP dialogues exceeded the high watermark threshold for SSN <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is reported when a threshold value has been reached.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the number of dialogs has exceeded the configured threshold value for the high watermark.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If the application cannot handle more dialogs, there is a risk for congestion. Otherwise, the maximum number of dialog resources will be reached.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The threshold value for the high watermark is to be checked. The number of dialog resources is to be increased.;If the threshold value for the high watermark is within the allowed range and the SSN cannot handle more dialogs, the traffic to this SSN is to be decreased.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The ss7TcapDialHighWatermark alarm will be cleared when the number of the existing dialogs becomes less than the threshold value for the low watermark. To avoid generating and clearing ss7TcapDialHighWatermark too many times, the threshold value for the low watermark can be decreased.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: -48V <A or B branch> is lost on the PIU.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when a PIU monitors no voltage on the incoming -48V. The same voltage monitoring is performed on the PFM, but will be reported as hw48VLostOnPfm.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: A power supply problem has occurred. Alarm text "-48V A is lost on the PIU" indicates that the PIU has no power supply from PFM A, and that this is probably due to a power supply problem with the PFM. Alarm text "-48V B is lost on the PIU" indicates that the PIU has no power supply from PFM B, and that this is probably due to a power supply problem with the PFM.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: One power supply is lost. If the other supply is lost too, the unit will shut down.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If temporary alarms are raised repeatedly during normal operation, generate a NodeDump and contact Ericsson support for further troubleshooting. For more information on how to generate a NodeDump, see #Data Collection Guideline#. If only one PIU (and no PFM) is reporting the problem, there is an internal power problem on the PIU. Replace the faulty PIU, see #Replacing a CMXB#, #Replacing an FSB#, #Replacing a GEP#, #Replacing an SCXB# or #Replacing an SMXB#. Check -48V LEDs according to Chapter 3.3 in #Replacing a Power and Fan Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the incoming -48V is corrected, for example, when the power source is fixed or faulty PIU or PFM is replaced.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The temperature on disk on <FsbId> is too high.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: The hwDiskTempHigh alarm is generated if the <FsbId> monitors a temperature that is too high in the unit. This can be due to the environment temperature or a hardware failure. This can occur, for example, when a fan breaks.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If the problem is not solved and temperature continues to rise, the unit will be shut down. Each unit has a local shut down logic, that in case of increased temperature levels shuts down the unit.

slot.name: action
slot.value: *If there are more temperature alarms check that the ambient temperature on the site is below 45 C degrees, and that the site cooling system works correctly. ;*Check for fan or power failures, and correct them where necessary. Clean or replace the dust filters in the cabinet. ;*If only one FSB has a too high disk temperature, then that FSB should be replaced as long as the another FSB is in sync and ready to act as primary FSB. ;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the temperature is below the allowed limit.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGW (<Name>, <Primary IP Address>) has been temporary unavailable <percent> percent of the time during the supervision period of <GwSupervisionPeriod> minutes.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This Alarm is generated when the percentage of supervision the period during which the SGW stays in the "temporary unavailable" status reaches the percentage threshold specified by the GwUnavailSupThreshold parameter.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated for each SGW when the percentage of the supervision period during which this SGW stays in the "temporary unavailable" status reaches the percentage threshold.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Consider checking the backbone network status and SGW node status.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared for each SGW when the percentage of supervision period during which this SGW stays in the "temporary unavailable" status is below the percentage threshold.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The primary BGw could not be contacted.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated for the push delivery mechanism when the primary BGw could not be contacted.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated if the primary BGw cannot be contacted, and therefore the secondary BGw is contacted. This alarm is generated when there is a failure in the network link as a result of hardware failure. It can also be generated if CDR-FTP service is not properly configured.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The secondary BGw is contacted. If it is raised due to CDR-FTP service mal-configuration, the secondary BGw will not be contacted, files can not be transferred to the Billing System and files will take a lot of disk space.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Temporarily: The secondary BGw is used automatically to ensure that the charging log files are forwarded from the target directory to the billing system.;Permanently: Use the following actions to stop the alarm:*Repair or replace the network link or use a bypass network link.;*Restart or repair the primary BGw. ;*Define a new primary BGw. If the alarm is raised due to CDR-FTP service, configure the service correctly.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: When the server has gone ready for the pull-function. Also when an rpc-call to the primary bgw was ok, and similar when an rpc-call both to the primary and secondary bgw was wrong. If the alarm was raised due to CDR-FTP service configuration, it will be cleared when CDR-FTP service is configured properly.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of Gbip NSEs has reached the maximum number of Gbip NSEs accepted by SGSN.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The admNseMaxNumberLimitReached alarm is generated if the total number of Gbip NSEs has reached the maximum number of Gbip NSEs accepted by SGSN. The maximum number of Gbip NSEs accepted by SGSN is configured by the #GbIpNseMaxNumber# parameter.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The total number of Gbip NSEs has reached the maximum number of Gbip NSEs accepted by SGSN. The maximum number of Gbip NSEs accepted by SGSN is configured by the #GbIpNseMaxNumber# parameter.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No more Gbip NSEs are accepted by SGSN. If the #GbIpNseMaxNumber# parameter is to set to a value less than the number of existing Gbip NSEs a number of NSEs exceeding the limit will automatically be deleted from the SGSN.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Increase the value of the #GbIpNseMaxNumber# parameter if the parameter was decreased by mistake. The #GbIpNseMaxNumber# parameter is only to be used in emergencies when the number of Gbip NSEs served by SGSN is to be temporary limited.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The total number of Gbip NSEs is less than the value of #GbIpNseMaxNumber# parameter.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The MME has lost the connection on the gtpv2-c path towards MSC= (<MscVlrName>) <AP Name> <MME VIP address>:<MME Port number><-><MSC node IP address> #Note: The MscVlrName is the MSC reference name for the configured MSC. The (<MscVlrName>) is omitted when the alarm is for an MSC discovered by DNS query.#

slot.name: description
slot.value: The gtpMscPathFailure alarm is generated when a GTPv2-C path failure is detected between an AP in the SGSN-MME and the MSC. This alarm is generated if the MSC does not respond to a GTPv2-C Echo Request message after N3RequestEchoSv attempts have been made.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm can be caused by a restart of the MSC or by a GTPv2-C path failure between the MSC and the MME.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Communication is not possible between the MME and the MSC that caused the alarm.

slot.name: action
slot.value: See Interface Problem in #Troubleshooting# for further information on how to investigate the reason for the failure.

slot.name: causeClear
additionalText
slot.value: The MME is congested. To protect the MME from overloading, the General NAS Level Mobility Management Congestion Control function for low access priority UE is activated.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The nasCongestionControlForLapi alarm is generated when the average CPU load of all APs reaches or exceeds the CPU threshold. The CPU threshold is predefined by the parameter LapiControlCpu.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the average CPU load reaches or exceeds the predefined CPU threshold.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The Attach Request or Service Request message from the low access priority UE is rejected.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the average CPU load is lower than 5 percent below the predefined CPU threshold.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The two redundant PFM units in a magazine must be of equal type, 2400 or 3200 Watt and LOD or HOD. Two PFM3200 in a pair must have the same power configurations 800/1600/2400/3200.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a PFM unit has the wrong type or an incorrect power configuration.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The hwPfmMismatch alarm is generated if there is a mismatch between the two redundant PFM units in a magazine.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The power supply to the magazine will not have redundancy, and may in some cases not provide any output voltage at all.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The two redundant PFM units have different types or different power configurations. Replace the improper PFM unit or ensure that the power configurations match.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the hardware is replaced or correctly configured.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when no active Routing Processor (RP) is available.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: When the alarm is generated, no RP is operating in the SGSN-MME. The SGSN-MME operates for a short period without an RP. If the alarm persists, it can result in routing and traffic failure in the SGSN-MME.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when an active RP is available.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The connection with the <Pod> is lost or can't be established.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The dpePodConnectionLost alarm is generated when a Pod is no longer responding or existing. The cause is either a hardware or software fault.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: A Pod is not responding or existing.;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The consequence depends on the role of the Pod. See Related Alarms and Events for further information on the consequences. The VNF may not operate with full capacity and it may have lost redundancy.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The trigger of the failure can be hardware or software related. Check the current state and recent events of the Pod.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the Pod is available again.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The number of available links for LinksetNo <number> to DPC <number> crossed the low watermark. Affected NodeID is <number>, with Local SPC <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The number of available links in the link set crossed the low watermark. This alarm is reported when a threshold value has been reached. For ITU and TTC standards, both the SPC and DPC values are printed in the format: 0-16383 and 0-65535 respectively. For ANSI and China standards, both the SPC and DPC values are printed in the format: 0-16777215 ([0-255]-[0-255]-[0-255]).

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the number of links that are in service for a particular link set falls below the configured threshold value.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: There is a risk for congestion.

slot.name: action
slot.value: **Some links are to be uninhibited. Other links should be returned to service.;**If this alarm occurs frequently, changes are to be made to handle additional capacity.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the number of links that are in service for the particular link set increased over the clearing threshold value

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: The sctpEventStorm alarm is generated in the following situations: 1. When storm of a specific SCTP event has been detected in the front-end process by exceeding the event-specific threshold. In this case the event that caused the storm is not reported for around 30 seconds. 2. When storm of a specific SCTP event has been detected in the SS7 O&M entity by exceeding the event-specific threshold. In this case the event that caused the storm is not reported for around 2 minutes.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value:
Depending on the original cause the following consequences are possible: 1. In case of event-specific storm detection in the SCTP front-end process the affected SCTP event from the affected process will not be reported until after around 30 seconds.
2. In case of event-specific storm detection in the SS7 O&M entity the affected SCTP event from all processes will not be reported until after around 2 minutes.

slot.name: action
slot.value: See the Actions to Be Taken for the discarded or deactivated SCTP event.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Depending on the original cause the sctpEventStorm alarm is cleared in the following cases: 1. In case of event-specific storm detection in the SCTP front-end process: The alarm is cleared after around 30 seconds. 2. In case of event-specific storm detection in the SS7 O&M entity: The alarm is cleared after around 2 minutes.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The remote processor has lost its processing power for the signaling link on <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The remote end of the signaling link is temporarily unavailable. The link is a narrowband signaling link with EqPos, trunk, and time slot.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated as a result of congestion at the remote side. The link is a narrowband signaling link with EqPos, Trunk and Timeslot.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The remote end of the link is temporarily unavailable and cannot handle any network traffic.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The module automatically starts a timer (T1). If this timer expires before the Remote Processor Outage has recovered, the traffic is automatically diverted to an alternative link and the link is realigned.;If this alarm occurs frequently, the load on the links is to be reduced by either adding additional links or by changing the routing priorities.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The admLicenseEmergencyState alarm is triggered when the SGSN-MME is in an emergency state, where the license mechanisms are set aside.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The emergency state is triggered by a CLI command entered by the operator.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The SGSN-MME will run without any license control for up to 14 days from the time the emergency state is entered by the CLI command.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Contact Ericsson support and request a new license key file with an emergency state unlock key.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: A license key file containing an emergency reset key is loaded.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGSN-MME has reached 95% utilization of the allocated hardware resources for IP sessions.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when 95% of the allocated hardware resources for IP Sessions is utilised by the SGSN-MME.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The reason for this alarm is that 95% of the allocated hardware resources for IP session is utilized by the SGSN-MME. The utilization is checked per board, and the alarm is raised when at least one board is above 95% hardware resource utilization. The monitored hardware resources are CPU load and memory usage.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Any attempt, for example, PDP context activation requests, inter-SGSN RAU requests with active PDP contexts, or PDN Connectivity requests by a UE to create new IP Sessions can be rejected.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Inform operator management that the utilisation of the hardware resources of the SGSN-MME is high enough that the admission of IP Sessions may be denied to protect the node from over load.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the utilization of the allocated hardware resources for IP Sessions is reduced below 90%.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of simultanously attached users on the node has reached the licensed capacity and the license enforces a hard limit.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of SAU in the GSN reaches the purchased capacity limit and the license enforces a hard limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when total number of SAU reached the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Any attempt by a new MS to enter the SGSN (e.g. attach request or inter-SGSN RAU) will be rejected as long as the number of SAU is equal to the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for number of SAU and check the network dimensioning and configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of SAU is reduced below 95% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Unable to look up notification definition in database. The original notification data was: <alarm>

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when no definitions for a certain alarm can be found in the fm_alarm_def database.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: Only the name of the original alarm can be seen.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Autonomous Mode has been activated. No connection to the NeLS server.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The admAutonomousModeActivated alarm is triggered when the License Manager on SGSN-MME loses its connection with NeLS server.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The NeLS configuration is configured and no connection with NeLS exists.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: When connection to NeLS server is lost Autonomous Mode is activated, meaning all license keys already retrieved will be kept during 7 days. When Autonomous Mode is expired the License Manager changes its state to LOCKED meaning no license keys are available. #Note: The admAutonomousModeActivated alarm is not cleared, when there is NeLS configuration, Autonomous Mode expired and there is no connection to NeLS server. Note#

slot.name: action
slot.value: When the admAutonomousAlarm is activated, check the configured parameters Host and Port are correct and also TLS configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when one of the following conditions is met: 1. Connection to NeLS server is restored. 2. NeLS configuration is removed.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The external server is not available for transfer of MDT Mapping event from <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The mdtmCommunicationFailure alarm is generated when the application layer has detected a failure in the communication with the external server during the near-real-time transfer process of the MDT Mapping events using TCP.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Failure in the communication with the external server.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The MDT Mapping events cannot be streamed to the receiving external server. The events may be lost if the alarm is not cleared within a few seconds. If the MDT Mapping events are configured to be logged to a file, as well as being streamed, the stored log files can be fetched manually by using SFTP.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: Successful connection to the external server.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when no standby RP is available.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: RP failover or RP switchover is not possible, no redundancy.

slot.name: action
slot.value: No action is normally required as the software restarts and recovers from this situation. If the alarm persists, do the following:**Ensure the routNoActiveRP alarm is not active.;**Ensure that the PIU running as standby RP is not blocked or removed for maintenance.;**If none of the above causes the alarm, then use the routActiveRP event to identify the NCB that has active RP role, and restart the other NCB that has the standby RP role using the restart_eqm_element CLI command.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when a standby RP is available. It can take up to 35 minutes for the standby RP to be available again. After a RP failover, the node may trigger a RP switchover and the alarm is generated again.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Remote SPC <number> unavailable. Affected NodeID is <number>, with Local SPC <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The SCCP network layer has received information from MTP-L3 or M3UA that a network node having a certain SPC is unavailable. For ITU and TTC standards, the SPC value is printed in the format: 0-16383 and 0-65535 respectively. For ANSI and China standards, the SPC value is printed in the format: 0-16777215 ([0-255]-[0-255]-[0-255]).

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The remote SPC is inaccessible due to failure or congestion. However SPCs are only available when the links or associations are activated, so the SPC may be unavailable due to normal circumstances. The status field of the failed SP is marked as Prohibited.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No SCCP user, that is, subsystem with an unique SSN, at the remote node can be reached by the users from this node.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Proceed as follows:*Check the log file for further details.;*If the unavailability of the remote SPC is due to MTP-L3 link or routing failure at or due to failure of the M3UA signaling association, traffic to the failed SPC should be stopped or reduced. Alternatively, additional links should be provided to the remote SPC.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the remote SPC becomes available.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Less than <GbIpNseAvailabilityDecreasedThreshold>% remote IP end-points available for NSEI <NSE ID>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The gbipNseAvailabilityDecreased alarm is generated when less than GbIpNseAvailabilityDecreasedThreshold percent of the currently known, remote IP endpoints of an NSE are accessible. Consequently, the capacity of the Gb interface with the BSS may be degraded.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: A remote IP endpoint, having failed the NS test procedures, is marked as suspect in the SGSN and blocked for traffic. The NS test procedure is performed on the Gb interface using the NS-ALIVE and NS-ALIVE-ACK messages. Remote IP endpoints that have been marked as suspect can be identified by using the #get_gb_ip_nse# CLI command. Accessible IP endpoints are marked as ok.; This alarm is generated when the ratio of the remote IP endpoints marked as ok falls under GbIpNseAvailabilityDecreasedThreshold percent per NSEI, compared to the total number of remote IP endpoints.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: When this alarm is active, the capacity of the Gb interface using the NSEI may be degraded, which may affect throughput for end-user traffic.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Verify the network connectivity to assure that IP routing is possible between all IP endpoints of the SGSN and the BSS (full-mesh connectivity). Involving the BSS O&M staff, verify that all IP endpoints configured in the BSS are locally available. Additional Information could be derived if the #gbipNseNsStatusReceived# event is generated for the same NSEI.

slot.name: causeClear
additionalText
slot.value: The node tried to send messages on the <service> IP-service, but this is not possible because the IP-service is not configured.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The gtpServiceNotConfigured alarm is generated when the node needs to send a GTP message on a GTP IP-service which is not configured.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the node tries to send a message on a GTP IP-service which is not configured.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No GTP messages can be sent on the affected IP-service, meaning that some procedures will no longer be possible to execute.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Configure the affected IP-service or check DNS configuration for co-operating nodes.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The affected IP-service is configured, or the alarm is manually cleared after it has been ensured that the triggering traffic case cannnot happen again.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is either malfunctioning or missing.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when an SMXB cannot communicate with an installed SFP/SFP+ transceiver. This indicates a hardware fault.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is raised when the SMXB is unable to read the transceiver status or EEPROM data from the SFP/SFP+ transceiver.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Verify that the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is correctly installed. Replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the communication with the transceiver is restored.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The DNS server <IP address> is unavailable. Cause: <Cause>.

slot.name: description
slot.value:
This alarm is related to the DNS supervision function, and not related to DNS queries that take place during UE signaling procedures. The DNS supervision function periodically performs DNS queries to all configured DNS servers and generates an alarm if a DNS server does not respond or responds with an error code.
The dnsServerUnavailable alarm is generated per DNS server. If all configured DNS servers have active alarms, the dnsAllServersUnavailable alarm is generated, while keeping the dnsServerUnavailable alarms active.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value:
This alarm is generated after a certain number of consecutive failed DNS supervision queries towards one DNS server. The maximum number of failed DNS supervision queries is configurable, using the #DnsSupervisionAttempts# parameter.
The <Cause> field in the alarm text indicates the reason why the DNS supervision query failed. When there is no response from the DNS server, the <Cause> field is set to 'timeout'. When the DNS server responds with an error code, the <Cause> field is set to this error code. Some examples of error codes are as follows (refer to the RCODE parameter in the DNS RFCs): - FORMERR: Format Error - SERVFAIL: Server Failure - NXDOMAIN: Non-Existent Domain (the name and the record type that SGSN-MME requested does not exist in the DNS server database.)

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The DNS server redundancy is affected.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
If the cause is 'timeout', check the followings: - IP connectivity toward the DNS server - DNS server is alive
If the cause is 'NXDOMAIN', check that the name and the record type of the DNS supervision query configured in SGSN-MME are provisioned in the DNS server.
For more information on how to investigate the reason of the failure, see DNS Related Faults in #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared at the next successful DNS supervision query toward the DNS server.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The remote event listener server is not available IP: <IP> port: <PORT>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The restServerNotResponding alarm is generated when the remote event listener server fails to send acknowledgement messages to the REST event service.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Communication to the remote event listener server failed.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The alarms cannot be streamed to the receiving remote event listener server.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Reconnect to the remote event listener server.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: This alarm can have several different reasons. The PFM may be missing altogether, the built-in selftest has detected a fault, there may be a firmware problem, or the the amount of current is out of bounds.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated if the PFM is missing altogether, if the built-in selftest has detected a fault, if there is a firmware problem, or if the amount of current is out of bounds.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The hwPfmOtherError alarm is generated if there is a miscellaneous PFM problem.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: This error can cause the PFM to provide incorrect cooling or power, or both..

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check that the PFM is properly inserted, connected, and configured. Upgrade the PFM to the latest firmware. For instructions, see #Upgrading MkX PFM Firmware#.If the problem persists, replace the PFM.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the hardware problem is corrected.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: A sector ID containing the market ID <MarketID>, switch number <SwitchNo>, cell <Cell>, and sector ID <SectorID> is received but can not be mapped to any IWS IP address.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the sector ID sent to the MME from the eNodeB does not match any configured sector ID range. As a result, the sector ID can not be mapped to any IWS IP address. The MME can raise the alarm for a maximum of 10 unmatched sector IDs simultaneously.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The received sector ID is not configured in the MME.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The UE can not fully utilize CS services in the specified sector.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check the configuration of the received sector ID.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: A configuration for the received sector ID is added in the MME.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: DHCP has failed to obtain an <IPv4 or IPv6> address for interface <ifname>, on <eqid>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The dhcpIpAddressNotObtained is generated when the DHCP client fails to obtain an IPv4 or IPv6 address.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the DHCP client fails to obtain an IPv4 or IPv6 address after the first initialization or when the lease expires.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The corresponding IP interface remains inactive because of the lack of an IPv4 or IPv6 address.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Validate the configuration of the DHCP server or the cloud infrastructure supporting the IP interface.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the DHCP client obtains an IPv4 or IPv6 address.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: The ss7EventStorm alarm is generated in the following situations: 1. When storm of a specific SS7 event has been detected in the front-end or back-end process by exceeding the event-specific threshold. In this case the event that caused the storm is not reported for around 30 seconds. 2. When storm of a specific SS7 event has been detected in the SS7 O&M entity by exceeding the event-specific threshold. In this case the event that caused the storm is not reported for around 2 minutes.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Depending on the original cause the following consequences are possible: 1. In case of event-specific storm detection in the SS7 front-end or back-end process the affected SS7 event from the affected process will not be reported until after around 30 seconds. 2. In case of event-specific storm detection in the SS7 O&M entity the affected SS7 event from all processes will not be reported until after around 2 minutes.

slot.name: action
slot.value: See the Actions to Be Taken for the discarded or deactivated SS7 event.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Depending on the original cause the ss7EventStorm alarm is cleared in the following cases: 1. In case of event-specific storm detection in the SS7 front-end or back-end process: The alarm is cleared after around 30 seconds. 2. In case of event-specific storm detection in the SS7 O&M entity: The alarm is cleared after around 2 minutes.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Node internal network problem from alarm originator to the PIU with address = <address>.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: A single PIU cannot be reached on one of the backplane right-side Ethernet networks.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the network problem is gone/corrected, for example, when the faulty PIU is replaced.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: No remote IP end-points available for NSEI <NSE ID>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The gbipNseUnavailable alarm is generated if none of the remote IP end-points of an NSE are accessible, resulting in the loss of its Gb interface.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: All remote IP endpoints have failed the NS test procedures, performed on the Gb interface using the NS-ALIVE and NS-ALIVE-ACK messages.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The Gb interface with the BSS identified by NSEI has been lost. No traffic can be carried over this interface. If this alarm is generated, it is still possible to display this NSE using the #get_gb_ip_nse# CLI command, but the BscConfirmed parameter is false, and the LocalGbIpEndpoint and RemoteGbIpEndpoint parameters have no information. The alarm #gbipNseAvailabilityDecreased#, if active, ceases.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: The BSS initiates a new SNS-SIZE procedure.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: BSSGP initialization failure due to Mobile Country Code and Mobile Network Code <MCC-MNC> is undefined. NSEI is <Nsei>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The nwcSpecificMccMncNotSet alarm is generated when the BSSGP initialization fails. This also means that the BVC reset procedure has failed.; It is due to undefined MCC and MNC of the PLMN. No BSSGP initialization and no traffic is possible until this specific MCC and MNC are defined.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the BSSGP initialization starts although a specific MCC and MNC are not defined.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No BSSGP initialization and no traffic is possible for this PLMN.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: The alarm will be cleared when the MCC and MNC has been configured.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The MME starts an overload protection of DDN throttling for low priority traffic at level 1.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when the MME load has reached or exceeded the predefined low CPU threshold at level 1.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the MME load has reached or exceeded the predefined low CPU threshold at level 1.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The MME activates the DDN throttling function for low priority traffic, and requests the SGW to reduce the number of Downlink Data Notification requests for low priority traffic, during a period of DDN throttling. The percent of the reducing number is specified by parameter DdnthrottlingFactor.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the MME load is lower than 5 percent below the predefined low CPU threshold at level 1.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Received optical power of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is above high threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the received optical power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is higher than the threshold level. This indicates a fiber/connector problem or an SFP/SFP+ malfunction.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the received optical power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is above the high threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check that the sending optical module in the external customer equipment is compatible with the SFP/SFP+ transceiver, that is reporting the alarm. Check if the optical module in the external customer equipment reports any alarms. If any, correct the reported alarms. If none of these options clears the alarm, replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the received optical power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The node is in maintenance mode.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated because of a severe software or configuration error. The SGSN-MME could go to maintenance mode if it fails to start normally. This can happen at initial startup and at software upgrade. When the SGSN-MME is in this mode, maintenance activities are needed.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a severe software or configuration error occurs.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The SGSN-MME is not in operation and only maintenance can be performed.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
If the SGSN-MME is in maintenance mode, the software upgrade or SGSN-MME startup has failed at some stage. The operator must decide on how to recover from maintenance mode.
1. Log on to the active NCB as O&M configuration operator.
2. Look at the last 50 messages in the ISP log file to see what has happened:
<userName>@<eqPos> ANCB ~ # tail -50 /tmp/DPE_COMMONLOG/isp.log;
The ISP log file provides information on which software configuration the SGSN-MME has attempted to start on and whether it was successful or if a fallback has occurred.
3. Verify the connection statistics using the following CLI command:
<userName>@<eqPos> ANCB ~ # eci stats;
The eci command output shows whether the SGSN-MME is carrying traffic.;;
To recover from maintenance mode, select one of the options described below:
*Option 1: Exiting Maintenance mode;
If the SGSN-MME is carrying traffic, it can be recovered from maintenance mode using the #exit_maint_mode# CLI command. This option can be used to avoid a restart, if the reason why the SGSN-MME is in maintenance mode is known, and if appropriate measures are taken to correct the faults.
1. Investigate and correct the faults. Decide if the measures taken to solve the faults are enough before continuing with the next step.
2. Exit maintenance mode and return the SGSN-MME into operational state using the following CLI command: <userName>@<eqPos> ANCB ~ # gsh exit_maint_mode
3. Collect as much logging data as possible. For detailed information about log files and troubleshooting, see #Troubleshooting#.
4. Report the incident to Ericsson support.
5. If step 2 fails, optionally perform a Manual Fallback or a Restore, see option 2 and 3 below.;
*Option 2: Performing a Manual Fallback;
If an older trusted SC is available, a Manual Fallback may be performed.
This option takes 10-15 minutes since it causes the SGSN-MME to restart.
1. Start the SGSN-MME on an older trusted SC (not LastBooted SC, Permanent SC). To revert to a trusted SC, perform the following: a. Log on to the active NCB.
b. Check which SCs are available by performing the following: <userName>@<eqPos> ANCB ~ # listSCs
c. Start the SGSN-MME on the SC that was used before by running the #manualSetSC# CLI command with root privileges: <userName>@<eqPos> ANCB ~ # sudo manualSetSC <SCName>
The SC is activated with the RebootNode activation method.
#Note: root privileges are gained by using the sudo OS command. Defining sudo rules for a user account allows this user account to use sudo. For information about how to define sudo roles, see #Operator Access Handling#.Note#
2. Collect as much logging data as possible. For detailed information about log files and troubleshooting, see #Troubleshooting#.
3. Report the incident to Ericsson support.
4. If step 1 fails, restore the SGSN-MME using a backup. For detailed instructions, see #Back Up and Restore SGSN-MME Using GSS# and #Back Up and Restore SGSN-MME Using Storage Server#.;
*Option 3: Restoring the SGSN-MME;
The SGSN-MME may be restored using a backup.
This option takes 20-30 minutes since it causes the SGSN-MME to restart and reinstall.
1. Collect as much logging data as possible. For detailed information about log files and troubleshooting, see #Troubleshooting#.
2. Report the incident to Ericsson support.
3. Restore the SGSN-MME using a backup. For detailed instructions, see #Back Up and Restore SGSN-MME Using GSS# and #Back Up and Restore SGSN-MME Using Storage Server#.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The SGSN-MME is started in normal mode.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of IP Sessions on the node is approaching the licensed capacity.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of IP Sessions in the SGSN-MME is approaching the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of IP Sessions exceeds 80% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: None. However, if the number of IP Sessions continues to rise, it can reach the licensed capacity limit of the node.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for the number of IP Sessions, or change network configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of IP Sessions is reduced below 70% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Initialization failure due to undefined Mobile Country Code and Mobile Network Code.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when there is no PLMN defined in the GSN. No traffic is possible until a PLMN is defined.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when no PLMN is defined in the GSN.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No traffic is possible in the GSN.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: The alarm will be cleared when the MCC and MNC have been configured.

slot.name: validFor
slot.value: SGSN-G; SGSN-W; CGSN; MME; AMF; QuicLink

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The PGW (<Name>, <Primary IP Address>) has been temporary unavailable <percent> percent of the time during the supervision period of <GwSupervisionPeriod> minutes.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This Alarm is generated when the percentage of the supervision period during which the PGW stays in the "temporary unavailable" status reaches the percentage threshold specified by the GwUnavailSupThreshold parameter.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated for each PGW when the percentage of the supervision period during which this PGW stays in the "temporary unavailable" status reaches the percentage threshold.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Consider checking the backbone network status and PGW node status.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared for each PGW when the percentage of the supervision period during which this PGW stays in the "temporary unavailable" status reaches is below the percentage threshold.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Internally measured temperature of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is below low threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the internal temperature of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is lower than the threshold level. This can be due to the temperature of the surroundings or an SFP/SFP+ transceiver malfunction.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the temperature of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is below the low threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check if the input cooling air temperature at site is within the operating temperature range for the SGSN-MME. Check if other transceiver alarms are reported on the same SFP/SFP+ transceiver. If the alarm is unique, replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the temperature of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The MME can start NAS congestion control. To protect the MME from overloading, the NAS Level Mobility Management Congestion Control function based on UE Priority is activated.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The nasCongestionControl alarm is generated when the average CPU load of all APs reaches or exceeds the minimum CPU threshold. The minimum CPU threshold is predefined by create_nas_congestion_control_profile.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the average CPU load reaches or exceeds the predefined minimum CPU threshold.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The Attach Request, Service Request, TAU Request or Control Plane Service Request message for the matched UE is rejected.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the average CPU load is lower than 5 percent below the predefined minimum CPU threshold.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Checkpoint the active configuration. The non-checkpointed configuration can be listed with the list_config_activated CLI command.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: *The configuration is checkpointed.;*A periodic backup is performed.;

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm indicates that the currently active configuration has not been checkpointed for at least 4 hours.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: In case of fallback, changing SC, or spontaneous or manual node restart the active configuration is lost.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the active configuration has not been checkpointed for at least 4 hours.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The number of established TCP connections towards SDS GW <SDS GW ID> is less than the MinimumTcpConnections parameter value <MinimumTcpConnections>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the number of established TCP connections towards an SDS GW is less than the MinimumTcpConnections parameter value, but greater than 0.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the number of established TCP connections towards an SDS GW is less than the MinimumTcpConnections parameter value, but greater than 0.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If this alarm is generated for the most preferred SDS GW, the MME selects the next most preferred SDS GW (if available) that has the number of established TCP connections equal or greater than the MinimumTcpConnections parameter value.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the number of established TCP connections towards the SDS GW is equal or greater than the MinimumTcpConnections parameter value or when the number of established TCP connections towards the SDS GW is 0.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: No Billing System is available for CDR transfer GTP Prime from:(<Hostname>) <SGSN VIP address>:<SGSN Port number1>,<SGSN Port number2>. BS1 failure:<Reason-BS1>. BS2 failure:<Reason-BS2>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The application layer has detected a communication failure to the Billing System during the near-real-time CDR transfer process using GTP'. The alarm is generated when both the primary and secondary GTP' receiver communication have failed, or when the primary GTP' receiver communication has failed and a secondary GTP' receiver is not specified.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Primary or secondary (if specified) GTP' Billing System communication failed.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The CDRs cannot be sent to the receiving billing system in near-real-time. If no connection is established within a couple of minutes, the CDRs will be stored in files within the SGSN. Then the billing system has to fetch the CDRs manually over the Gom interface using SFTP or any other appropriate file transfer protocol.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Maintenance activities need to be initiated to remove the communication failure. Repair IP network to billing system or restart applications on billing system. Check for busy Billing System, or communication failure towards the Billing Systems

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Successful connection to primary or secondary Billing System.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value:
An Alarm Storm refers to a situation where there are 30 alarms from one specific SCTP front-end during a three second period, or 120 alarms from many SCTP front-ends during a 60 second period.
The sctpAlarmStorm alarm is generated in the following situations:
1. When storm of a specific SCTP alarm has been detected in the front-end by exceeding the alarm-specific threshold. In this case the alarm that caused the storm is not reported for around 30 seconds.
2. When storm of a specific SCTP alarm has been detected in the SS7 O&M entity by exceeding the alarm-specific threshold. In this case the alarm that caused the storm is not reported for around 2 minutes.
3. When storm of SCTP alarms has been detected in the front-end by exceeding the general threshold. Alarms and events covered by alarm and event specific protection respectively are not taken into account. In this case a number of alarms and events from the affected process are discarded until the alarm and event rate decreases. If the alarm is raised with this cause, a clear timer (around 2 minutes) is started.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value:
Depending on the original cause the following consequences are possible: 1. In case of alarm-specific storm detection in the SCTP front-end process: The affected SCTP alarm from the affected process will not be reported until after around 30 seconds. The affected SCTP alarm from the affected process can be cleared even if the problem reported in the alarm is present.
2. In case of alarm-specific storm detection in the SS7 O&M entity: The affected SCTP alarm from all processes will not be reported until after around 2 minutes. The affected SCTP alarm from all processes will be cleared even if the problem reported in the alarm is present.
3. In case of general alarm storm detection in the SCTP front-end process a number of SCTP alarms from the affected process will not be reported until the alarm rate decreases.

slot.name: action
slot.value: See Actions to Be Taken for the discarded or deactivated SCTP alarm. The SCTP alarm name is stated in the alarm text.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value:
Depending on the original cause the sctpAlarmStorm alarm is cleared in the following cases:
1. In case of alarm-specific storm detection in the SCTP front-end process: The alarm is cleared after around 30 seconds.
2. In case of alarm-specific storm detection in the SS7 O&M entity: The alarm is cleared after around 2 minutes.
3. In case of general alarm storm detection in the SCTP front-end process: The alarm is cleared after around 2 minutes.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: All the Gb over IP NSEs are removed.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The admGbIpNseUnavailableStorm alarm is generated when there is a storm of gbipNseUnavailable alarms. This occurs when the SGSN-MME removes all the Gb over IP NSEs during an SC activation with the activation method RestartApplications.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the SGSN-MME removes all the Gb over IP NSEs during a software update with the activation method RestartApplications.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The consequence of this alarm is that the traffic is interrupted on the Gb over IP interface during the software update. The traffic is automatically re-established after the software update of the SGSN-MME.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Wait for all the Gb over IP NSEs to automatically re-establish. The time for this alarm to clear depends on the number of Gb over IP NSEs. If this alarm is not automatically cleared after the software update, refer to #Troubleshooting# for more information about Gb over IP interface problems.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when all the Gb over IP NSEs are automatically re-established after the software update of the SGSN-MME.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of simultaneously attached users on the routing area with identity <MCC-MNC-LAC-RAC> has reached 95% of the system defined hard limit.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of SAU in one RA has reached 95% of the system defined hard limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is triggered when: *The total number of SAU in one RA has reached 95% of the system defined hard limit.;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Any attempt (for example, attach request or inter-SGSN RAU) by a new MS to enter the RA will be rejected.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Inform operator management that the SAU per RA limit is reached.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when: *the total number of SAU in one RA has been reduced to 90% of the system defined hard limit.;

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The maximum number of measurement type readings per occasion (<number>) is crossed.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The threshold of the counter pmReadingsPerOccasion has been reached.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the threshold of the counter pmReadingsPerOccasion is reached. This can happen if the threshold is lowered after the jobs have been started, after a configuration change adding MO instances which report measurement values, or after a software upgrade where new measurement types have been added to pm groups which are included in measurement jobs. It is not allowed to activate a job if the threshold would be reached.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: It is not possible to activate any new measurement jobs.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Stop or delete or modify one and if necessary more measurement jobs.; Change the threshold and hysteresis level so that the number of measurement type readings per occasion is below the hysteresis.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the number of measurement type readings per occasion has reached the alarm-clearing threshold.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The FSB with hostname <FsbHostname> has lost connectivity with the GSS server.

slot.name: description
slot.value:
The fsbGssBackupServerDown alarm is only generated when the backup manager called system is enabled and when the connection between an FSB and the GSS server is lost or when an FSB fails to establish a new connection towards the GSS server. If the connection problem is on the GSS server side, each FSB generates an alarm independently.
The hostname <FsbHostname> that is mentioned in the alarm text can take either of the following values: *fsb1: the alarm concerns the leftmost FSB; *fsb2: the alarm concerns the rightmost FSB; #Note: This alarm is only applicable when using GSS server. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The connection between the FSB and the GSS server is lost or the FSB fails to establish a new connection towards the GSS server due to any of the following reasons: *The GSS server is not available;*A network problem between the FSB and the GSS server;*The DHCP service on the GSS server is not working;*Problem with the front Ethernet port on the FSB; #Note: The alarm is not triggered directly when the connection is lost. The connection is checked when an action is triggered either by the user or internally and this action requires the GSS, and the connection is checked automatically once every hour. Note#

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The following operations cannot be performed when the connection towards the GSS server is lost:;*Backup;*Restore;*Software upgrade using GSS;*FSB replacement;

slot.name: action
slot.value: 1. Check if the GSS server is available. Try to log on to the GSS server through the O&M network. 2. Check if the DHCP service on the GSS server is running and that the DHCP service is correctly configured. 3. Check the connection between the FSB and the GSS server. Run the GSA command #info# with root privileges or through the FSB console. When the FSB successfully connects to the GSS server, the GSS server information is printed. #Note: root privileges are gained by using the sudo OS command. Defining sudo rules for a user account allows this user account to use sudo. For information about how to define sudo rules, see #Operator Access Handling#.Note# 4. If the GSS server is fully functional but the FSB still has no contact with the GSS server, check the Ethernet switch and cabling.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the FSB successfully connects to the GSS server.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value:
Depending on if an M3UA association has gone down, or was unable to be established, the following alarm-information is valid:
- If an association has gone down the alarm contains the parameters RemoteSpId, LocalSpId, SctEndPointNo, SCTP reason and Origin. The SCTP reason contains the event type that took place when communication was lost. This alarm indicates that SCTP has lost communication with an end-point completely or detects that the remote node performed an Abort (Peer Requested Abort) or Shutdown operation (Peer Requested Terminate).
SCTP reason =========== The SCTP Reason parameter is the failure reason returned by SCTP in an SCTP_COMM_LOST_ind.
Values and descriptions ----------------------------------- 1: Initiation Failure, max INIT retransmits reached. 2: Shutdown Failure, max SHUTDOWN retransmits reached. 3: ULP Requested Terminate. 4: Undetermined Error. 5: Peer Requested Abort. 6: Max Retransmits Failed, no peers responding. 7: Inbound Streams Not Opened. 8: Outbound Streams Not Opened. 9: Resource Error, local resources. 10: Invalid INIT ACK. 11: Peer Requested Terminate. 12: No User Data In Chunk. 13: Data reassembly error. 14: Wrong Stream Sequence Number. 15: Invalid Sack Chunk. 16: Stale Cookie Error. 17: Local Requested Abort. 18: Invalid stream Id has been detected. 19: Mandatory parameter is missing. 20: Address can not be resolved. 21: Mandatory parameter is invalid. 22: Association has been restarted with new IP addresses. 23: Serious protocol violation has been detected.
- If an attempt to establish an association failed the alarm contains the parameters RemoteSpId, LocalSpId, SctpEndPointNo, Establish Failure (EF) cause and SCTP return code (or SCTP reason). For EF cause 1, the SCTP reason is the failure reason returned by SCTP in an SCTP_COMM_LOST_ind. For EF cause 3, the SCTP return code contains the return code from the SCTP_ASSOCIATE_conf message. The reason for this could be either misconfiguration of the remote IP address or that the remote IP address is not available. If several remote IP addresses have been configured M3UA will try to establish the association using the next remote IP address in the configured list of remote IP addresses.
Establish Failure =================
Values and descriptions ----------------------------------- 1: SCTP_COMMLOST_ind received while waiting for association establishment. 2: T-AssocAck timer (parameter M3UA TimerTassoc) expiration while waiting for association establishment. 3: SCTP_ASSOCIATE_conf returned error code (parameter SCTP Return Code). Association configuration error.
SCTP Return Code ================ The SCTP Return Code parameter is the return code parameter returned by SCTP in an SCTP_SEND_FAILURE_ind or SCTP_ASSOCIATE_conf.
Values and descriptions ----------------------------------- 0: OK 1: Maximum number of instances reached. 2: Invalid transport address. 3: Invalid sctpInstanceId. 4: Specified IP address incorrect. 5: OutboundStream parameter incorrect. 6: Invalid address type. 7: No more buffer space. 8: Connection is closing down. 9: Invalid assocId. 10: Maximum number of associations reached. 11: Internal error. 12: Primitive wrong format. 13: No user data. 14: Invalid streamId. 16: Invalid module ID. 17: Invalid user module ID. 18: Invalid user distributor module ID. 19: Invalid client mode. 20: Maximum number of user instances reached. 21: Invalid DSCP. 22: User is already bound to SCTP. 23: SCTP couldn't get the local IP addresses from the IP layer. 24: Invalid interface version. 25: SCTP user not bound. 26: Primitive received in wrong state. 27: Duplicate Initialize form the SCTP user instance.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Signaling over this M3UA association is impossible.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the association is operational again, that is, when the association establishment has been successful.

slot.name: description
slot.value:
This alarm is related to the DNS supervision function, and not related to DNS queries that take place during UE signaling procedures. The DNS supervision function periodically performs DNS queries to all configured DNS servers and generates an alarm if a DNS server does not respond or responds with an error code.
The dnsServerUnavailable alarm is generated per DNS server. If all configured DNS servers have active alarms, the dnsAllServersUnavailable alarm is generated, while keeping the dnsServerUnavailable alarms active.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when DNS supervision queries toward all configured DNS servers are failing.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If none of the configured DNS servers respond, this can lead to major service outage. The negative consequences are highly dependent on the current level of adequate content of the SGSN-MME DNS caches. If the record is cached, DNS queries can succeed even after the record expires. (A record expires when the time-to-live value of the NCB and AP BIND caches time-to-live value is exceeded.) DNS queries can succeed due to the resilience cache, which is the indefinitely stored AP Application Layer cache. Assuming this alarm is triggered, the DNS queries fail in the following scenarios: - A query response record is not previously known by the SGSN-MME - The operator 'clear_dns' command is issued - A Node restarts DNS server provisioning does not affect until the DNS connectivity is restored. Note: The 'dump_dns' command does not dump the AP Application Layer cache.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
Check the dnsServerUnavailable alarm(s) to find the cause of the failure.
For more information on how to investigate the reason of the failure, see DNS Related Faults in #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared at the next successful DNS supervision query toward any DNS server.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: <Number of bad nodes> bad node internal network paths detected from alarm originator.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: Several PIUs cannot be reached on one of the backplane left-side Ethernet networks.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the network problem is gone/corrected, for example, when the faulty PIU is replaced.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Tx bias current of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is below low threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the current Tx bias of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is lower than the threshold level. This indicates an SFP/SFP+ malfunction.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the current Tx bias of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is below the low threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Ensure that the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is operated during normal conditions. Check if the #transceiverTempHigh#, #transceiverTempLow#, #transceiverVoltageLow#, or #transceiverVoltageHigh# alarms are also reported from the same SFP/SFP+ transceiver. If none of the alarms are reported, replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the current Tx bias of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The value of measurement type <measurement type> has reached its threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the value of a supervised counter or gauge has reached its alarm triggering level.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The value of a supervised counter or gauge has reached its predefined threshold value. The triggering level is defined by an operator using the #set_pm_sup# CLI command.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Consequence depends on the actual measurement type.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Proposed solution depends on the actual measurement type, see #Counter Description#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm will be cleared when the value has reached its predefined value for clearing the alarm. The value for clearing the alarm is defined by an operator using the corresponding CLI command.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: A TA RAT type received in an S1 Setup Request or eNB Configuration Update message from <eNodeB_Type> eNodeB <eNodeB_Id> in PLMN <MCC-MNC> <with eNodeB name eNodeB_Name> conflicts with the RAT type configured for this TA.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated if a TA RAT type received in an S1 Setup Request or eNB Configuration Update message from an eNodeB is inconsistent with the RAT type configured through the accessRatType parameter for this TA.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is trigger when: *A TA RAT type received from an eNodeB conflicts with the RAT type configured for this TA.; #Note:If more than one RAT type is received, the alarm is generated if any of the received RAT type is inconsistent with the RAT type configured through the accessRatType parameter for this TA.Note# For information regarding the current network configuration, see the appropriate network planning documentation.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The MME will return an S1 Setup Failure or eNB Configuration Update Failure message to the eNodeB.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check whether the TA RAT type received from an eNodeB is the same as the RAT type configured for this TA. All the alarms that are older than 24 hours will be cleared. To force clearing of alarms before 24 hours have elapsed, use the clear_alarms CLI command. For more information, see #S1-MME Interface Description#.

slot.name: causeClear
additionalText
slot.value: Ethernet port <magazine.slot.position>:<port> actual parameters mismatch with configuration.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the ethernet port Auto Neg results in different linespeed, or duplex mode, or both, than what was configured via CLI. This can occur when the ethernet port is configured with 1 Gbps linespeed (Auto-Negotiation on) while the ethernet network or the remote node only supports 100Mbps.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Linespeed and/or duplex mode, configured by CLI, do not correspond to the actual parameters of a port.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Ethernet capacity/speed may be less than expected.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check Ethernet port CLI configuration so that it matches the actual port capacity.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Linespeed and/or duplex mode, configured by CLI, are the same as the actual parameters of a port.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The association to <eNodeB_Type> eNodeB <eNodeB_Id> in PLMN <MCC-MNC> <with eNodeB name eNodeB_Name> is lost. <SCTP cause is [corresponding cause] Origin is [local user_remote user].>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The eNodeB is unreachable because the SCTP association to an eNodeB is lost. #Note: If many eNodeBs are unreachable, not all of the epsEnodeBUnreachable alarms are triggered. Only the number of alarms that are set in the MaxEnodeBUnreachableAlarms parameter are triggered.The total number of unreachable eNodeBs is counted in the gauge VS.MM.NbrDisconnectedeNodeB.E. To see all the unreachable eNodeBs, run the show_mme_global_enodeb CLI command using the -ens disc parameter value.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
