slot.value: An SCTP association between MME and an eNodeB is lost. The cause may be network failure, an eNodeB restart, an SCTP device failure or other configuration/timing problem(s). For common causes displayed due to association loss, see #diameterConnectionDown#.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: There is no contact with the eNodeB. The MME changes the state to ECM-IDLE for any UE handled by the eNodeB, and updates the bearer by sending a request to the SGW.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Restore the SCTP association or the eNodeB. For more information on the handling of unreachable eNodeBs, see #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The SCTP association between MME and the eNodeB is established or the eNodeB data in MME is deleted.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The value of measurement type <measurement type> has reached its threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: Generated when the value of a supervised counter or gauge has reached its alarm triggering level.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The value of a supervised counter or gauge has reached its predefined threshold value. The triggering level is defined by an operator using the #set_pm_sup# CLI command.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Consequence depends on the actual measurement type.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Proposed solution depends on the actual measurement type, see #Counter Description#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm will be cleared when the value has reached its predefined value for clearing the alarm. The value for clearing the alarm is defined by an operator using the corresponding CLI command.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: EBM output buffer overflow has occurred on <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The ebmStreamBufferOverflow alarm is generated when the Event-Based Monitoring PDU output buffer on one AP has reached its maximum size limit, and the maximum size limit is 600000 events. This occurs due to the external system being unavailable or busy.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the output buffer has reached its maximum size limit. The reasons for this may be either, or both, of the following: *Busy external system;*Unavailable external system, that is, a communication error;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Event-Based Monitoring events stored in the output buffer on the AP are lost.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If the alarm is generated due to unavailable Event-Based Monitoring server, perform the following steps. **Follow the actions to be taken in the alarm #ebmCommunicationFailure#, in order to solve the communication failure.;**If the Event-Based Monitoring events are configured to be logged to file, in addition to being streamed, the stored Event-Based Monitoring log files can be fetched manually by using SFTP.; Another alarm has already been sent about the communication failure.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The output buffer usage has decreased below its hysteresis value for alarm clearance.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGSN-MME has reached 95% utilization of the allocated hardware resources for attached users.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when 95% of the allocated hardware resources for attached users is utilised by the SGSN-MME.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The reason for this alarm is that 95% of the allocated hardware resources for attached users is utilized by the SGSN-MME. The utilization is checked per board, and the alarm is raised when at least one board is above 95% hardware resource utilization. The monitored hardware resources are CPU load and memory usage.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Any attempt, for example, attach request or inter-SGSN RAU by a new UE to enter the SGSN-MME may be rejected.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Inform operator management that the utilisation of the hardware resources of the SGSN-MME is high enough that the admission of new users may be denied to protect the node from over load.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the utilization of the allocated hardware resources for attached users is reduced below 90%.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Tx output power of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is above high threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the transmitted optical power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is higher than the threshold level. This indicates a fiber or connector problem, or an SFP/SFP+ malfunction.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the Tx output power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is above the high threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check the SFP/SFP+ transceiver, fiber, and connector integrity. Replace the SFP/SFP+ module if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the Tx output power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: BVC Reset has not been responded from BSS on BVC number <BVC number> for NSE number <NSE number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The bssgpBvcResetRetriesExceeded alarm is generated because of no available NS-VC, no acknowledgement on BVC Reset PDUs has been received from the BSS. It is not possible to use the BVC to send GPRS traffic.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the SGSN has repeatedly sent BVC-RESET PDUs towards the BSS but the BSS has not responded with a BVC-RESET-ACK PDU.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: It is not possible to use the BVC to send GPRS traffic, because contact to the peer is not available.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Perform the following steps: **Check the total status of remote IP endpoints (TotalEndpointStatus) for this Network Service Entity (NSE), by using the #get_gb_ip_nse# CLI command.;**If the TotalEndpointStatus parameter is ok, reinitiate BVC reset, by using the #action_ptp_bvc_reset# CLI command.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: *The NSE is deleted;*The SGSN initiates a reset;*The BSS initiates a reset (both for signaling and PTP BVC);

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Too high voltage on -48V <A or B branch>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated if the PFM monitors too high voltage on the incoming -48V. No voltage level monitoring is performed on the other PIUs.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: A power supply problem has occurred. The hw48VHigh alarm is generated when there is too high voltage on the incoming -48V.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If the problem is not solved and the supply voltage continues to rise, the unit will shut down. Each unit has a local shut down logic, that in case of increased temperature levels shuts down the unit.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Is the voltage more than the maximum allowed nominal voltage? Check the site power supply system to see if it reports any problems. Refer to the documentation for that system for more information on fault analysis and replacement of faulty components. If there are no problem with the power supply system, then try and replace the reporting PFM, see #Replacing a Power and Fan Module#. Contact Ericsson support if the problem is not corrected.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the voltage on the incoming -48V is within the limits again.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The PLMN Identity/Identities <PLMNList> received in an NG Setup Request from gNodeB <gNodeB_Id> in PLMN <MCC-MNC> <with gNodeB name gNodeB_Name> is not configured in the AMF.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The PLMN Identity (or identities) received in an NG Setup Request from the gNodeB is not configured in the AMF.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The AMF will return an NG Setup Failure to the gNodeB.

slot.name: action
causeClear
additionalText
slot.value: The total number of simultaneously attached IoT users on the MME is approaching the licensed capacity.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of IoT SAU on the MME is approaching the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when when the total number of IoT SAU exceeds 80% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: None. However, if the number of IoT SAU continues to rise it can reach the licensed capacity limit of the MME.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for the number of IoT SAU or change the network configuration

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of IoT SAU is reduced to below 70% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGSN has lost the connection to the GGSN = <GGSN main IP address>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The gtpGgsnBlacklisted alarm is generated when a GGSN is not responding to a Create PDP Context Request message after N3RequestCreate attempts. The GGSN Blacklisting feature is no longer available for new customers.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The gtpGgsnBlacklisted alarm is generated when a GGSN is not responding to a Create PDP Context Request message after N3RequestCreate attempts.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: It is not possible to create new PDP contexts towards the node that caused the alarm.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check the external node that caused the alarm or wait until the restart is finished.

slot.name: causeClear
additionalText
slot.value: This alarm is generated when two or more APs or DPs are unavailable.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when two or more APs and/or DPs are unavailable.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when two or more APs and/or DPs are unavailable.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The SGSN-MME may not be able to handle normal traffic load and may experience overload situations. This may imply that the SGSN-MME is perceived as unavailable to subscribers.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Troubleshooting is required unless the condition is purposely inflicted, for example, by O&M manually blocking the equipment. For more information regarding PIU or VM Failure, see #Troubleshooting#. Contact Ericsson support if the problem is not corrected.

slot.name: related
slot.value: dpePIUConnectionLost, nocBoardAutoBlocked, nocPMFailure, nocNodeOutOfService, nocSmallLocalRestart, nocSmallRestart, nocLargeRestart, nocNodeRestart

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the lost APs or DPs are available again.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the Ethernet port does not receive any signal from the carrier. This indicates a remote peer down, SFP/SFP+ problem, or a cable problem. #Note: For MkX, if this alarm is generated, the bfdNeighborDown alarm is not generated. Note# #Note: The alarm is sent using UDP, therefore there is a risk that the alarm does not reach the OSS when sent by the SNMP trap. If the alarm does not reach the OSS, this indicates a temporary disturbance in the network used to send the trap. To ensure that the SNMP trap reaches the OSS, use an SNMP INFORM message. SNMP INFORM messages can result in higher network traffic. For more information about SNMP, see #Configuring Fault Management#. For more information about SNMP INFORM, see #SNMP - Ericsson Alarm MIB (CLI)#. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The signal is lost on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No traffic can be sent or received on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
For MkVIII, do the following: 1. Check the local and remote peer configurations. 2. Check the Ethernet port cabling and replace any faulty cabling. 3. Replace the APP if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an APP#. 4. Replace the SFP module if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#. 5. Replace the PIU that is used as a router board (SCXB or CMXB) if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an SCXB# or #Replacing a CMXB#. 6. Check that the speed of the equipment that is connected to the APP is within requirements. For more information, see #Active Patch Panel (APP)#.
For MkX, do the following: 1. Check the local and remote peer configurations. 2. Check the Ethernet port cabling and replace any faulty cabling. 3. Replace the SFP/SFP+ module if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#. 4. Replace the SMXB if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an SMXB#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The signal is received on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when a Fan Unit fault is detected by < PFM A or B >. The blue Maintenance LED is lit to indicate that replacement of the PFM is needed.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The hwFanError alarm is generated if the PFM reports a fan error.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The magazine may be overheated causing the PIUs to shut down.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check that the fans are functioning properly, for example, that the motors are working, that the fans are rotating, and that the power distribution is working correctly. Replace the PIU where the fan is located.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the hardware problem is corrected.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of simultaneously attached LTE users has reached the purchased capacity limit and the license enforces a hard limit.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users reaches the purchased capacity limit and the license enforces a hard limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users reaches the purchased capacity limit and the license enforces a hard limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Any attempt by a UE to enter the MME (for example, attach request or inter-MME TAU) is rejected as long as the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users is equal to the purchased capacity limit .

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for LTE SAU, and check the network dimensioning and configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users is reduced below 95% of the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Event size exceeds the limit of 2 MB. <RemovedSize> MB of excess data has been removed.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The restEventContentSizeLimitReached alarm is generated when the REST event content size is exceeding a limit of 2MB.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The REST event content size has exceeded the 2MB limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: A portion of the REST event content was removed.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Decrease the number of measurement readers for the OnapJobOpt Performance Measurement Job.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The REST event content must be under the limit of 2MB.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The connection with the <EqId> is lost or can't be established.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The dpePIUConnectionLost alarm is generated when a PIU or VM is no longer responding or not existing. The cause is either a hardware or software fault.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: A hardware unit is not responding.;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The consequence depends on the role of the PIU or VM. See related alarms and events for further information on the consequences. The SGSN-MME may not operate with full capacity and it may have lost redundancy.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The trigger of the failure can be hardware or software related. See PIU or VM Failure in #Troubleshooting# for further information on how to investigate the reason for the failure.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the PIU or VM is available again.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGSN has lost connection with the RNC=<rnc_name>

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the SGSN has received the message Rnc_out_of_service from the link between the SGSN and the configured RNC. The reason for this might be congestion, or that the RNC has restarted. #Note: The alarm is only generated if the configured RNC was in service before. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The signal from the RNC is lost.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No communication is possible between the SGSN and the RNC in question.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Wait until the RNC has restarted. If the alarm corresponds to an RNC that has been removed from the SGSN, it must be cleared manually using the clear_alarms CLI command. A large restart will also clear the alarm.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Signalling is restored towards the RNC.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGSN-MME has entered failsafe state due to lack of some vital processing resources.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the SGSN-MME has entered failsafe state due to lack of vital processing resources.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The SGSN-MME is incapable of executing normal operation and is, therefore, placed in failsafe state. SGSN-MME resumes normal operation when the processing resources are available again.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Troubleshooting is required unless the condition is purposely inflicted, for example, by O&M manually blocking the equipment. For more information regarding PIU or VM failure, see #Troubleshooting#. Contact Ericsson support if the problem is not corrected.

slot.name: related
slot.value: dpeEquipmentBlocked, dpeNodeInMaintenanceMode, dpePIUConnectionLost, gsnStartCompleted, gssNoOperationalSS7Device, nocAPTakeOver, nocAPTakeOverFailed, nocBoardAutoBlocked, nocDPTakeOver, nocDPTakeOverFailed, nocHardwareLoss, nocLargeRestart, nocNodeRestart, nocPMFailure, nocSmallLocalRestart, nocSmallRestart

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared in case processing resources become available again and the SGSN-MME resumes normal operation.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: There is a power supply problem.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when the PFM monitors no voltage on the incoming -48V that supplies the PFM. The green LED is off.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: A power supply problem has occurred. The PFM may lack primary power supply from the front cables, or secondary power supply from the backplane. In the latter case, the fault is probably due to a problem with the primary power supply to the other PFM.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: One power supply is lost. If the other supply is lost too, the unit will shut down.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check -48V LEDs on the PFMs and fuses on the external power supply system. If both the PFMs and all other PIUs in the same magazine reports the problem, the external power supply A or B is missing. Check the power supply system to see if it reports any problems.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the hardware problem is corrected.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: MDT Mapping output buffer overflow has occurred on <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The mdtmLoggingBufferOverflow alarm is generated when the PDU output buffer of MDT Mapping on one AP has reached its maximum size limit, and the maximum size limit is 600000 events. This occurs due to failure of logging or other reason.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the output buffer has reached its maximum size limit. The reasons for this may be either, or both, of the following: *Failure of logging;*Other reason;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: MDT Mapping events stored in the output buffer on the AP are lost.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: The output buffer usage has decreased below its hysteresis value for alarm clearance.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The MSC/VLR <MscVlrName> cannot be reached. <SCTP cause is [corresponding cause] Origin is [local user_remote user].>

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the SGSN-MME cannot reach any of the SGs peers configured for an MSC/VLR over the SGs interface on the configured IP address(es). The alarm displays the MscVlrName.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the last SCTP association towards an MSC/VLR has failed, or when an attempt to create the first SCTP association towards an MSC/VLR has failed. For common causes displayed due to association loss, see #diameterConnectionDown#.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: There is no communication over the SGs interface between the MME and the MSC/VLR. No Mobile Terminated (MT) or Mobile Originated (MO) SMS can be handled by the MME for UE associated to the affected MSC/VLR.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If the alarm does not clear itself the following can be checked: Is the MSC/VLR operational? Is the physical connection between the MME and the MSC/VLR in order? Is the MSC/VLR and SCTP peer configuration in the MME correct?

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the SCTP association is established.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of simultaneously attached LTE users is approaching the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users is approaching the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users is approaching 80% of the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: None. However, if the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users continues to rise, it can reach the purchased capacity limit of the node.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Consider extending the license for LTE SAU, and check the network dimensioning and configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users is reduced below 70% of the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Temperature too low in the unit.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when the PIU monitors too low temperature in the unit. The red Fault LED is lit until the alarm is cleared.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The hwTempLow alarm is generated if the PIU monitors a temperature that is too low in the unit, due to the environment or a hardware failure. This can occur, for example, when the temperature sensor breaks.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If the problem is not solved and temperature continues to fall, the unit will be shut down. Each unit has a local shut down logic, that in case of decreased temperature levels shuts down the unit.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If only one PIU has too low temperature, then replace that PIU. If there are more temperature alarms check that the ambient temperature on the site is above 5 C degrees, and that the site cooling system works correctly.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the temperature is within the limits again.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGW (<Name>, <Primary IP Address>) is unstable, and its status has changed <GwStatusFlipTimes> times during the supervision period of <GwSupervisionPeriod> minutes.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This Alarm is generated when the number of times the SGW status changes from "available" to "temporary unavailable" reaches the configured threshold during the supervision period. The threshold is specified by the GwStatusFlipTimes parameter.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated for each SGW when the number of times the status of this SGW changes from "available" to "temporary unavailable" reaches the flip threshold during the supervision period.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Consider checking the backbone network status and SGW node status.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared for each SGW when the number of times the status of this SGW changes from "available" to "temporary unavailable" is below the flip threshold during the supervision period.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Internally measured supply voltage of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is above the high threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the internally measured supply voltage of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is higher than the threshold level. This indicates an SFP/SFP+ malfunction or an SMXB port problem.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the supply voltage of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is above the high threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check if other SFP/SFP+ transceivers in the same SMXB also report #transceiverVoltageHigh# alarms. In this case, replace the SXMB. For more information, see #Replacing an SMXB#. If the alarm is raised on the particular SFP/SFP+ transceiver, replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the internally measured supply voltage of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: An automatic large restart has occured.

slot.name: description
slot.value: An automatic large restart has been triggered.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated when a software or hardware failure resulting in an indeterminate node state has occurred.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: All subscribers in the SGSN-MME are lost. Affected MSs and UEs are not notified.

slot.name: action
slot.value: This alarm needs to be cleared by the operator, using the #clear_alarms# CLI command. If the alarm was caused by a software error, relevant logs should be made available to Ericsson for analysis. For more information about what logs to collect, see #Troubleshooting# and #Data Collection Guideline#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is not automatically cleared by the SGSN-MME except after the next node reload, and therefore needs manual clearing by the operator.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The value of measurement type <measurement type> has reached its threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The pmSupThresholdCrossedMaj alarm is generated when the value of a supervised counter or gauge has reached its alarm triggering level. #Note: This is a generic alarm decoupled from the application stepping the counter.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The value of a supervised counter or gauge has reached its predefined threshold value. The triggering level is defined by an operator using the #set_pm_sup# CLI command.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Consequence depends on the actual measurement type.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Proposed solution depends on the actual measurement type, see #Counter Description#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm will be cleared when the value has reached its predefined value for clearing the alarm. The value for clearing the alarm is defined by an operator using the corresponding CLI command.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when an internal PFM power supply fault is detected.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when an internal PFM power supply fault is detected.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The PFM will not be able to supply other PIUs with power.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The problem is due to an internal PFM fault. Replace the faulty PFM, see Replacing a Power and Fan Module.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the hardware problem is corrected.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Local Congestion on signaling link on <number> indicated from link layer.

slot.name: description
slot.value: MTP-L3 will stop signaling on the specified link since MTP-L2/SAAL-NNI or lower level suffers from congestion. The link is a narrowband signaling link with EqPos, trunk, and time slot.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: A Local Link congestion primitive is received from the link layer. This primitive is used for alerting level 3 on the fact that level 2 or lower level suffers of congestion on the specified Link. The link is a narrowband signaling link with EqPos, Trunk and Timeslot.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: This causes the event machine to put the internal state into its RPO state without starting the surveillance timer T1.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The PLMN Identity/Identities <PLMNList> received in an S1 Setup Request or eNB Configuration Update from <eNodeB_Type> eNodeB <eNodeB_Id> in PLMN <MCC-MNC> <with eNodeB name eNodeB_Name> is not configured in the MME.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The PLMN Identity (or identities) received in an S1 Setup Request or eNB Configuration Update from the eNodeB is not configured in the MME.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The MME will return an S1 Setup Failure or eNB Configuration Update Failure to the eNodeB.

slot.name: action
causeClear
additionalText
slot.value: The value of measurement type <measurement type> has reached its threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the value of a supervised counter or gauge has reached its alarm triggering level.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The value of a supervised counter or gauge has reached its predefined threshold value. The triggering level is defined by an operator using the #set_pm_sup# CLI command.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Consequence depends on the actual measurement type.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Proposed solution depends on the actual measurement type, see #Counter Description#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm will be cleared when the value has reached its predefined value for clearing the alarm. The value for clearing the alarm is defined by an operator using the corresponding CLI command.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The PGW (<Name>, <Primary IP Address>) is unstable, and its status has changed <GwStatusFlipTimes> times during the supervision period of <GwSupervisionPeriod> minutes.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This Alarm is generated when the number of times the PGW status changes from "available" to "temporary unavailable" reaches the configured threshold during the supervision period. The threshold is specified by the GwStatusFlipTimes parameter.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated for each PGW when the number of times the status of this PGW changes from "available" to "temporary unavailable" reaches the flip threshold during the supervision period.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Consider checking the backbone network status and PGW node status.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared for each PGW when the number of times the status of this PGW changes from "available" to "temporary unavailable" is below the flip threshold during the supervision period.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: One or several SCTP associations towards the MSC/VLR <MscVlrName> has failed. <SCTP cause is [corresponding cause] Origin is [local user_remote user].>

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the signalling over SGs towards an MSC/VLR is degraded.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the communication over SGs towards an MSC/VLR has degraded due to loss of one or several, but not all SCTP associations, towards an MSC/VLR. This alarm is also generated when an attempt to create additional associations with an MSC/VLR, already having at least one working SCTP association, has failed. For common causes displayed due to association loss, see #diameterConnectionDown#.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The connection towards the MSC/VLR is not fully redundant.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If the alarm does not clear itself the following can be checked: Are the MSC/VLR and the SCTP peer configurations in the MME correct? Is the physical connection between the MME and the MSC/VLR in order?

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: All SCTP associations causing the alarm are established.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The secondary File Server Board (FSB) has replaced the failing primary FSB, but the file system of the new primary FSB is either corrupt or out of sync.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The primary File Server Board (FSB) failed, and was therefore replaced by the secondary FSB. The file system of the new primary FSB is either corrupt or out of sync.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Because of the file system of the new primary FSB being corrupt or out of sync, the SGSN-MME availability can be affected.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Restore or reinstall the SGSN-MME. For MkVIII and MkX, see #Back Up and Restore SGSN-MME Using GSS# and #Back Up and Restore SGSN-MME Using Storage Server#. For configuration backup on all platforms, see #Back Up and Restore the SGSN-MME Configuration#. For virtual SGSN-MME, see #Back Up and Restore Virtual SGSN-MME Using Snapshot#. If the SGSN-MME is working and switching traffic, avoid any disk-intensive manual actions such as creating or deleting Software Configurations (SCs), creating a checkpoint, or performing a backup. If possible, do not restore or reinstall the SGSN-MME during traffic-intense hours.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: BFD session to neighbor <IPv4 or IPv6 address> on the <network> network is down.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The bfdNeighborDown alarm is generated when a BFD session to a neighbor is down. #Note: For MkX, this alarm is not generated if the ethLinkDown alarm is generated. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a BFD session has no connectivity with a BFD neighbor. Possible causes for this include link failure, switch failure, router failure or missing BFD configuration at the BFD neighbor router.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: A redundant network path will be used. Possible performance downgrade for routing and links, and can also lead to traffic disturbance.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the BFD session has re-established connectivity with the BFD neighbor.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Remote Alarm Indication (RAI) is detected on PCM trunk <Trunk>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm ss7Mtpl1RemoteAlarmIndication is raised when a remote peer sends a Remote Alarm Indication (RAI) to the SGSN. The RAI is sent when the remote peer has lost the frame alignment or the signal on the uni-directed link from the SGSN to the remote peer.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The lost frame alignment is caused by poor transmission quality on the uni-directional link from the SGSN to the remote peer. Poor transmission quality can be caused by poor electrical connections or other interference giving intermittent bit errors.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The remote peer receives traffic of poor transmission quality from the SGSN.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Do one or several of the actions below: - Set the interface in SGSN in loop back mode and start a loop back test of the interface from the remote peer. - Perform visual check of interface cable. - Restart the SS7 front end PIU in the SGSN. - Connect the cable to a different port.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The association to the MCE <Mce_Id> is lost. <SCTP cause is [corresponding cause] Origin is [local user_remote user].>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The MCE is unreachable because the SCTP association to the MCE is lost. #Note: If a large number of MCEs are unreachable, only the first ten epsMceUnreachable alarms are raised. The total number of unreachable MCEs is measured using the VS.EMBMS.NbrDisconnectedMce.E gauge.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: An SCTP association between MME and an MCE is lost. The cause may be network failure, an MCE restart, an SCTP device failure or other configuration/timing problem(s). For common causes displayed due to association loss, see #diameterConnectionDown#.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: There is no contact with the MCE. The MME does not send any MBMS session related message to the MCE.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Restore the SCTP association to the MCE.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The SCTP association between the MME and the MCE is established or the MCE data in the MME is deleted.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: A backup has been interrupted. The reason is: <reason>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when a backup is interrupted from starting or completing. The reason for the failure needs to be investigated.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm can be triggered for any of the following reasons: - Heavy disk usage on primary FSB - Too large backup size - Corrupt backup - Failure during backup creation because of any of the following reasons:*The FTP put command failed with fault code 31.;*The pipeline terminated with fault code 32.;*The mkfifo function failed with fault code 41.;*Transfer failed with fault code <another fault code>.; - Insufficient disk space on GSS server or local storage - No connection to GSS server - Unable to log on to the GSS server - Incorrect file/directory permissions for the user on GSS server

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Future backups could fail if the causes of failure remain unsolved.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If possible, correct any problems described as reasons in the alarm text and make a new backup. For further assistance, call Ericsson support and provide the specific reasons and fault codes shown in the alarm text.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The next successful backup clears the alarm.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The MME has lost the S10 connection on the gtpv2-c path towards MME = < MMEC>: <remote S10 IP address>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when the GTPv2-C path between two MMEs in the pool is down.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the remote MME does not respond to a GTPv2-C Echo Request message after retransmissions. This is caused by one of the following reasons: - Remote MME restart - Remote MME outage - S10 path failure

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: It is not possible for the serving or backup MME to send or retrieve UE-geo replicas from the remote MME, which may impact the UE restoration procedure. The geo-replicas from the serving MME will be distributed to the other available MMEs in the pool during the path failure.

slot.name: action
slot.value: To clear this alarm, do the following: 1. Check the status of the remote MME. 2. If the remote MME is up and running, troubleshoot S10 interface problems. See #Troubleshooting# for further information.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the remote MME responds to a GTPv2-C Echo Request message.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Node internal network problem from alarm originator to the PIU with address = <address>.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: A single PIU cannot be reached on one of the backplane left-side Ethernet networks.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the network problem is gone/corrected, for example, when the faulty PIU is replaced.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Signaling link on <number> is out of service. Status is <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: A signaling link has been put out of service as an error occurred on the link layer or physical layer. The link is a narrowband signaling link identified by EqPos, trunk, and time slot.;The hardware used for the link has entered its out of service phase.;This alarm is not triggered when a narrowband SS7 front end PIU is blocked, instead the #ss7Mtpl3LPOrcv# alarm is raised. However, no alarm is raised if the PIU is permanently blocked when the SGSN is started. For more information, see #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The link has been put out of service, as an error has occurred on the link or physical layer.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The hardware used for this link has entered its out of service phase. This stops link activity.

slot.name: action
additionalText
slot.value: The total number of simultaneously attached users on the node has exceeded the licensed capacity.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of SAU in the GSN exceeds the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when total number of SAU exceeds the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: None. However if the number of SAU continues to rise it may reach the capacity limit of the node.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for number of SAU and check the network dimensioning and configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of SAU is reduced below 95% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Received optical power of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is below low threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the received optical power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is lower than the threshold level. This indicates a fiber/connector problem or an SFP/SFP+ malfunction.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the received optical power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is below the low threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check that the sending optical module in the external customer equipment is compatible with the SFP/SFP+ transceiver, that is reporting the alarm. Check if the optical module in the external customer equipment reports any alarms. If any, correct the reported alarms. Check that the correct type of optical fiber is used. Check bending radius or other damage to the fiber. Clean all optical fiber connections. For more information, see #Cleaning Optical Fiber Cables#. If none of these options clears the alarm, replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the received optical power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The primary Billing System is not available for CDR transfer GTP Prime from: (<Hostname>) <SGSN VIP address>:<SGSN Port number>. BS failure: <Reason-BS1>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The application layer has detected a communication failure to the Billing System during the near-real-time CDR transfer process using GTP'. The gtpprimeBSPrimaryLinkDown alarm is generated only when the primary GTP' receiver communication has failed and a secondary GTP' receiver is specified.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated when only the primary GTP' receiver communication failed and a secondary GTP' receiver is specified.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The secondary GTP' link is used instead and a redundant link is no longer functional.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Maintenance activities need to be initiated to remove the communication failure. Repair IP network to billing system or restart applications on billing system.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Successful connection to primary Billing System.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Logging failed while processing <name of the file and directory>. <failure and cause>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The logging function could not access its disk partitions. Data can not be written to the log or log files can not be wrapped (or both).

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: Data can not be written to log or log files can not be wrapped (or both).

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check the sum of the maximum log size for all logs and delete unnecessary files from the disk partition of logging.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm needs to be manual cleared.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated when one of the following occurs:*Frequent large restarts that are escalated to a reload. This is indicated by the following alarm text, where <AP> is the e-node that initiated the reload: The reload was initiated by <AP>.;*A processing module failure or capsule failure that cannot be handled by a less extensive restart level. This is indicated by the following alarm text, where <AP> is the e-node that initiated the reload: The reload was initiated by <AP>.;*Sometimes the cause of the node reload cannot be determined. This can occur in connection with software upgrade using the activation method restartDPE or RebootNode. It can also occur when the SGSN-MME reloads because of a watchdog timeout, causing the PIUs or VMs to restart. This is indicated by the following alarm text: The node failed to identify the trigger for this node reload. For reloads caused by upgrades, the following alarm text can be displayed: The reload was initiated by restart_node_script.;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: All subscribers in the SGSN-MME are lost. Affected MSs and UEs are not notified. A restart on the permanent or current SC is performed.

slot.name: action
slot.value: This alarm needs to be cleared by the operator, using the #clear_alarms# CLI command.; If the alarm was caused by a software error, relevant logs should be made available to Ericsson for analysis. For more information about what logs to collect, see #Troubleshooting# and #Data Collection Guideline#.;If the alarm text indicates that the cause of the node reload could not be determined with certainty, additional information about the reload can be found in the log file isp.log.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is not automatically cleared by the SGSN-MME except after the next node reload, and therefore needs manual clearing by the operator.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Loss of signal is detected on PCM trunk <Trunk>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the E1/T1 interface does not receive any signal. This could indicate a cable problem or remote peer down

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Loss of signal is detected, meaning that no signal to the board is detected for this trunk.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No signaling over the links on this trunk is possible.

slot.name: action
slot.value: A visual check of the interface cable should be performed. The remote peer configuration should also be checked.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of simultaneously attached LTE users has exceeded the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users exceeds the purchased capacity limit and the license enforces a soft limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users exceeds the purchased capacity limit and the license enforces a soft limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: None. However, if the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users continues to rise, it can reach the capacity limit of the node.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for LTE SAU, and check the network dimensioning and configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of simultaneously attached LTE users is reduced below 95% of the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: description
causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The consequences are critical, as all SS7 based signaling procedures to and from this SGSN are interrupted. Attached and active subscribers might be able to continue for a while, but no new subscribers are possible to attach.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when at least one PIU or VM executing SS7 functionality becomes available.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: <magazine.slot.2.1>: Multiple ISL or cross connections are lost.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when two or more nonadjacent Inter-Subrack Links (ISL) or cross connections are lost between the SMXBs. The alarm is not generated when only two adjacent links fail since this occurs every time an SMXB is restarted or blocked. All SMXBs have one logical connection with every other SMXB to ensure Ethernet redundancy. In a normal state, one of the MTP/MPO links between two of the SMXBs is always blocked for traffic. If there is a single link loss, the blocked MTP/MPO link is deblocked and the connectivity between the SMXBs remains. This indicates an MTP/MPO cable problem, or an SMXB port problem. Multiple link faults can lead to node degradation. For more information, see #Resilience#.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Multiple ISL or cross connection faults. This alarm is only raised by SMXBs located in the first magazine. Each SMXB raises the alarm independently. If both boards are in the same ring segment, only the left-hand side SMXB raises the alarm.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Node degradation, traffic loss, internal network problems, and external signalling problems. Backplane redundancy loss.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check for #redEthRingConnectionFault# alarms and correct them. Replace the SMXB if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an SMXB#.

slot.name: related
slot.value: redEthRingConnectionFault, redEthSingleFaultNet1, redEthSingleFaultNet2, redEthMultiFaultNet1, redEthMultiFaultNet2, hwFiberLinkError

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the connection problem is resolved.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The E-SMLC <ipaddress> cannot be reached. <SCTP cause is [corresponding cause] Origin is [local user_remote user].>

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the SGSN-MME cannot reach the E-SMLC over the SLs interface on the configured IP address(es). The alarm displays the primary IP address only.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when an attempt to create an SCTP association towards an E-SMLC has failed. Or when an existing SCTP association towards an E-SMLC is lost. For common causes displayed due to association loss, see #diameterConnectionDown#.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: There is no communication over the SLs interface between the MME and the E-SMLC. No location service request procedure can be handled by the affected E-SMLC. If an alternative E-SMLC is available, the MME uses that instead.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If the alarm does not clear itself the following can be checked: Is the E-SMLC operational? Is the physical connection between the MME and the E-SMLC in order? Is the E-SMLC and SCTP peer configuration in the MME correct?

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the SCTP association is established.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The external LDAP servers are unavailable.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The ldapServerUnavailable alarm indicates that an LDAP request to the configured external LDAP servers has timed out.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when no response withavalidBase DNis returned from any configured external LDAP server after five consecutive connection attempts. A new connection attempt is performed every 60 seconds.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Users cannot logon to the SGSN-MME using an external user account because the configured external LDAP servers are not available.

slot.name: action
slot.value: For information about how to investigate the reasons for the failure, see #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when any of the following condition is met: - At the next successful LDAP request to a configured external LDAP server - When the configurations of the external LDAP servers are removed from the SGSN-MME

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: IP Path from <EqId> to <EqId> on Internal-2 network is down. Either vLC is not responding or Internal-2 network is dropping packets.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The ipPathSupervisionFailure alarm is generated when a GPB or an NCB has no connectivity with a vLC on the Internal-2 network. #Note: This alarm is generated only if internalPathSupervision is enabled. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated because of the following causes: *Failures in NFVI such as switch failure, link failure, or host restarts;*Hypervisor errors preventing vLC role to execute;*Software errors on vLC;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: A redundant egress network path is used if available. vLC ingress traffic targeting the fault reporting VM may be lost while the alarm is raised.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Take the following actions according to the relevant causes: *Block the VM running the vLC role and verify the integrity of the IP connectivity of the compute resource hosting vLC role if multiple path failure alarms are reported for the vLC.;*Block the fault reporting GPB or NCB and verify the integrity of the IP connectivity of the compute resource hosting the GPB or NCB if a single path failure is reported.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the fault reporting GPB or NCB re-establishes connectivity with the supervised vLC.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: MDT Mapping output buffer overflow has occurred on <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The mdtmStreamBufferOverflow alarm is generated when the PDU output buffer of MDT Mapping has reached its maximum size limit of 600,000 bytes on one AP. This occurs if the external system is unavailable or busy.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the output buffer has reached its maximum size limit. The reasons for this may be either, or both, of the following: *Busy external system;*Unavailable external system, that is, a communication error;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: MDT Mapping events stored in the output buffer on the AP are lost. If the MDT Mapping events are configured to be logged to a file, as well as being streamed, the stored log files can be fetched manually by using SFTP.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If the alarm is generated due to unavailable external server, follow the actions to be taken in the alarm #mdtmCommunicationFailure#, in order to solve the communication failure. Another alarm has already been sent about the communication failure.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The output buffer usage has decreased below its hysteresis value for alarm clearance.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The external server is not available for transfer of EBM event from <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The ebmCommunicationFailure alarm is generated when the application layer has detected a communication failure to the external server during the near-real-time transfer process of the Event-Based Monitoring events using TCP.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Communication failed to the external Event-Based Monitoring server.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The Event-Based Monitoring events cannot be streamed to the receiving external server. The events may be lost if the alarm is not cleared within a period of some seconds.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Maintenance activities need to be initiated to remove the communication failure if the alarm is persistent. Check the configured server address and port using the #get_event_job# CLI command with the -epi EBM -eji EbmStream parameters. Repair IP network to the external server or restart applications on the external server. Check for busy external EBM server, or communication failure towards the external server. If the EBM events are configured to be logged to file, in addition to being streamed, the stored EBM log files can be fetched manually by using SFTP.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Successful connection to the external Event-Based Monitoring server.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: None of the SDS GWs can be reached.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the MME cannot reach any SDS GW over the SGs-Lite interface, that is, when the sdsGatewayUnreachable alarm is generated for each SDS GW. #Note:This alarm is related to a restricted feature and not for general use.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when none of the SDS GWs can be reached.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The Short Data Service over the SGs-Lite interface is unavailable.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when any of the SDS GWs can be reached or all SDS GW data is deleted from the MME.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Tx bias current of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is above high threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the current Tx bias of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is higher than the threshold level. This indicates an SFP/SFP+ malfunction.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the current Tx bias of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is above the high threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Ensure that the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is operated during normal conditions. Check if the #transceiverTempHigh#, #transceiverTempLow#, #transceiverVoltageLow#, or #transceiverVoltageHigh# alarms are also reported from the same SFP/SFP+ transceiver. If none of the alarms are reported, replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the current Tx bias of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Login attempts for <uid> have reached the configured alarm threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: If a user fails authentication a specified number of times, a security alarm is raised. The number of failed authentications for a user is reset any time the authentication succeeds or following the removal of the user lockout, if the lockout occurred due to authentication failure.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The user failed login attempts has reached the configured failed login alarm threshold.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared if the user successfully logs in, or if the account lockout is removed for the user.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Problem with HW product info or flash PROM on element <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the PIU has problems accessing its flash PROM. The probable cause is malfunctioning equipment.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The SGSN-MME or PIU may not work properly.

slot.name: action
additionalText
slot.value: The total number of IP Sessions on the node has exceeded the licensed capacity.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of IP Sessions in the SGSN-MME exceeds the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of IP Sessions exceeds the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: None. However if the number of IP Sessions continues to rise, it can reach the capacity limit of the node.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for the number of IP Sessions and check the network dimensioning and configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of IP Sessions is reduced below 95% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: <magazine.slot.2.1>: The ISL or the cross connection to <adjacent board magazine>.<adjacent board slot> is lost.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the ISL (Inter-Subrack Link) or the cross connection between the alarm originator and the remote SMXB is lost. In a normal state, one of the MTP/MPO links between two of the SMXBs is always blocked for traffic. If there is a single link loss, the blocked MTP/MPO link is deblocked and the connectivity between the SMXBs remains. This indicates an MTP/MPO cable problem, or an SMXB port problem. Multiple link faults can lead to node degradation. Each SMXB raises the alarms independently of the other SMXBs. For more information, see #Resilience#. #Note: This alarm is only applicable for the 10G backplane network. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is raised when an adjacent SMXB is not reachable through the ISL or the cross connection.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Replace the MTP/MPO cable between the alarm originator and the remote SMXB. Replace the SMXB if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an SMXB#.

slot.name: related
slot.value: redEthRingMultipleFaults, redEthSingleFaultNet1, redEthSingleFaultNet2, redEthMultiFaultNet1, redEthMultiFaultNet2, hwFiberLinkError

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the connection problem is resolved.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Measurement type <name of measurement> has exceeded its threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The nocSupervisedMeasWar alarm is generated when a counter or gauge supervised by the performance management function has exceeded its defined alarm threshold. #Note: This is a generic alarm decoupled from the application stepping the counter.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a supervised counter or gauge has exceeded its predefined threshold value. The triggering level is defined by an operator using the #set_pm_sup# CLI command.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The consequence of the alarm depends on the current measurement type.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Proposed solution depends on the actual measurement type, see #Counter Description# and #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the supervised counter or gauge has reached its predefined value for clearing the alarm. The value for clearing the alarm is defined by an operator using the corresponding CLI command.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Cell Trace Mapping output buffer overflow has occurred on <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The cellTraceLoggingBufferOverflow alarm is generated when the PDU output buffer of Cell Trace Mapping on one AP has reached its maximum size limit, and the maximum size limit is 600000 events. This occurs due to failure of logging or other reason.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the output buffer has reached its maximum size limit. The reasons for this may be either, or both, of the following: *Failure of logging;*Other reason;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Cell Trace Mapping events stored in the output buffer on the AP are lost.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: The output buffer usage has decreased below its hysteresis value for alarm clearance.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The external server is not available for transfer of Cell Trace Mapping event from <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The cellTraceCommunicationFailure alarm is generated when the application layer has detected a failure in the communication with the external server during the near-real-time transfer process of the Cell Trace Mapping events using TCP. The alarm is valid for the LTE radio access type.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Failure in the communication with the external server.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The Cell Trace Mapping events cannot be streamed to the receiving external server. The events may be lost if the alarm is not cleared within a few seconds. If the Cell Trace Mapping events are configured to be logged to file, as well as being streamed, the stored log files can be fetched manually by using SFTP.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: Successful connection to the external server.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of simultaneously attached IoT users on the MME has exceeded the licensed capacity.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of IoT SAU on the MME exceeds the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when total number of IoT SAU exceeds the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: None. However, if the number of IoT SAU continues to rise it can reach the capacity limit of the MME.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for the number of IoT SAU and check the network dimensioning and configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of IoT SAU is reduced to below 95% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Measurement type <name of measurement> has exceeded its threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: A counter or gauge supervised by the performance management function has exceeded its defined alarm threshold. #Note: This is a generic alarm decoupled from the application stepping the counter.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a supervised counter or gauge has exceeded its predefined threshold value. The triggering level is defined by an operator using the #set_pm_sup# CLI command.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The consequence of the alarm depends on the current measurement type.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Proposed solution depends on the actual measurement type, see #Counter Description# and #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the supervised counter or gauge has reached its predefined value for clearing the alarm. The value for clearing the alarm is defined by an operator using the corresponding CLI command.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: At least one TA received in an S1 Setup Request or eNB Configuration Update message from <eNodeB_Type> eNodeB <eNodeB_Id> in PLMN <MCC-MNC> <with eNodeB name eNodeB_Name> is not configured in the MME.

slot.name: description
slot.value: At least one TA received in an S1 Setup Request or eNB Configuration Update message from the eNodeB is not configured in the MME.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The MME will return an S1 Setup Failure or eNB Configuration Update Failure message to the eNodeB.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check that TA configurations are consistent between the eNodeB side and the MME side. All nwcEnodeBTaiMismatch alarms that are older than 24 hours will be cleared. To force clearing of alarms before 24 hours have elapsed, use the clear_alarms CLI command. For more information regarding handling of disconnected eNodeBs, see #S1-MME Interface Description#.

slot.name: causeClear
additionalText
slot.value: Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port > failed in negotiating parameters with remote peer.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the Ethernet interface cannot negotiate correct speed and duplex parameters with the peer.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: No traffic can be sent or received on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm will be cleared if Auto-Negotiation is disabled or the peer device report that it supports Auto-Negotiation.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The threshold for trusted certificate <trustedCertName> expiration has been crossed, and the certificate must be replaced before <validTo> to prevent secure service failure.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The threshold for trusted certificate expiration has been crossed, and the certificate must be replaced to prevent secure service failure.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated only if there is a risk of causing failure of secure service.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: This alarm indicates that a trusted certificate is about to expire and a replacement is needed to prevent secure service failure.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Replace the certificate. For more information see #Configuring Certificate Management#. #Note: in the case of restricted trusted certificates, call Ericsson support.Note#

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared by replacing the TrustedCertificate MO.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Internally measured temperature of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is above high threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the internal temperature of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is higher than the threshold level. This can be due to the temperature of the surroundings or an SFP/SFP+ transceiver malfunction.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the temperature of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is above the high threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check if the input cooling air temperature at site is within the operating temperature range for the SGSN-MME. Check the PFM air filter cleanness. Clean or replace the air filter, if needed. For more information, see #Replacing a PFM Dust Filter#. Check if other transceiver alarms are reported on the same SFP/SFP+ transceiver. If the alarm is unique, replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the temperature of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGSN has lost the connection on the gtpc path = (<Hostname>) <SGSN VIP address>:<SGSN Port number><-><External node address> (Connection between this node and the external node)

slot.name: description
slot.value: The gtpPathFailureControlPlane alarm is generated when a GTP-C path between an SGSN-MME and a GGSN is down.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when an external node, such as, GGSN or SGSN does not respond to a GTP Echo Request message after N3GnCRequestEcho or N3GpCRequestEcho attempts. This can be caused by a node restart or a GTP-C path failure.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Communication is not possible between the SGSN-MME and the node that caused the alarm. If the alarm is caused by a GGSN, the SGSN-MME may initiate a PDP context restoration procedure depending on the configuration of the Gateway Restoration Procedures feature. #Note: There are no consequences for existing PDP contexts resulting from the path failure. New requests for existing and new PDP contexts can still be sent but are likely to be unsuccessful, since there is a problem with the path. Note#

slot.name: action
slot.value: See Interface Problem in #Troubleshooting# for further information on how to investigate the reason for the failure.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the SGSN-MME sends control signals towards the node that caused the alarm and succeeds.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: EBM output buffer overflow has occurred on <EqId>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The ebmLoggingBufferOverflow alarm is generated when the Event-Based Monitoring PDU output buffer on one AP has reached its maximum size limit, and the maximum size limit is 600000 events. This occurs due to failure of logging or other reason.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the output buffer has reached its maximum size limit. The reasons for this may be either, or both, of the following: *Failure of logging;*Other reason;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Event-Based Monitoring events stored in the output buffer on the AP are lost.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: The output buffer usage has decreased below its hysteresis value for alarm clearance.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: A manual large restart has occured.

slot.name: description
slot.value: A manually triggered large restart has restarted the application software on all APs.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a manual interaction with the system has triggered a large restart.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: All subscribers in the SGSN-MME are lost. Affected MSs and UEs are not notified.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is not automatically cleared by the SGSN-MME except after the next node reload, and therefore needs manual clearing by the operator.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The certificate <CertName> is expired or unavailable, risking failure of secure service.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The certificate for the alarming object is expired, revoked, or unavailable, risking failure of secure service.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated when no valid certificate is available when a secured service is invoked.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: This alarm indicates that a secure service failed due to an expired, revoked, or non-existing certificate.

slot.name: action
slot.value: For more information see #Configuring Certificate Management#. #Note: in the case of restricted node credentials, call Ericsson support.Note#

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared by performing an initial enrollment for the CREATED or INVALID NodeCredential MO or by removing the users of the MO.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: *Time Sync: NTP daemon not synchronized *Time Sync: NTP daemon not synchronized (External NTP server *Server IP address* is unavailable)

slot.name: description
slot.value: The Network Time Protocol (NTP) daemon (xntpd) on the Node Controller Board (NCB) requires a clear User Datagram Protocol (UDP) connection on port 123. The NTP daemon chooses one of the external NTP servers as a system peer host and that host is used as a primary server for time synchronization. The NTP daemon uses the Active Node Controller Board (ANCB) as an external NTP server on the following hardware: - MkVIII: Application Processor (AP) boards and Passive Node Controller Board (PNCB) - MkX: AP boards, PNCB, and Subrack Main Switch Board (SMXB) The existing hosts can be displayed using the #list_ntp_server# or #list_ntp_ipv6server# CLI command. The number of external hosts and the status of the NTP daemon on the external hosts, affect the synchronization status. It is recommended to configure at least four external NTP servers to discard false-tickers. #Note: After a restart, it can take several minutes before the NTP daemon has stabilized and the alarm is cleared. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: For ANCB, the alarm is generated when one or more external NTP servers that are configured on NCB are not marked as system peer hosts. Lack of system peer host can be caused by connectivity problems between the NCB and the remote node. For APs, PNCB, and SMXB, the alarm is generated when the time offset between the individual board and the ANCB is greater than 2.5 seconds.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The node fails to maintain synchronized time internally and externally with respect to the absolute time (UTC).

slot.name: action
slot.value: Investigate why NTP cannot reach the configured external hosts. If necessary, it is recommended to configure at least four external NTP servers using the #create_ntp_server# CLI command. The alarm can also be raised for PNCB, APs, or SMXB boards indicating a similar error and therefore a similar solution applies.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value:
For ANCB, the alarm is cleared when all the configured external servers are marked as system peer hosts.
For APs, PNCB, and SMXB, the alarm is cleared when the time offset between the individual board and the ANCB is less than 1.5 seconds.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: No SS7 signalling possible due to undefined SGSN ISDN number.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The nwcIsdnNumberNotSet alarm is generated when the SS7 signaling procedures fail due to undefined ISDN number of the SGSN. No SS7 signaling is possible unless the ISDN number of the SGSN is defined. Examples of SS7 signaling procedures are fetching authentication triplets from the HLR or the GPRS update location.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is triggered when the ISDN number of the SGSN has not been defined in the system.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the ISDN number has been defined for the first time.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The connection to DF2 <DF2 Name> is down. Cause: <reason>. See the LI User Instruction, 19/198 17-CRA 250 56/1, for more information.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: Loss of external clock source(s) is detected.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: When both external clock sources are lost, communication problems (for instance more bit errors) may occur.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check the clock source status with CLI #show_ss7_mtpl2_clocksrcstat#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: Connection to the failing external clock source(s) is restored.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The Erlang clock and the system clock differs more than 1 minute and the CDR accuracy is affected. The clocks should be synchronized within <time> minutes.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is sent when the Erlang clock and the system clock differ more than 1 minute and the operator needs to decide if a restart is needed to resolve CDR accuracy. The delay until the clocks are synchronized is also stated in the alarm. During all this time, CDRs are generated with the wrong time, and tariff changes do not work as expected. #Note: If the physical SGSN-MME has been powered off or been powerless for more than 10 minutes, the internal clock (used by Erlang) is initiated with a start time that cannot be corrected with a large leap, in the same way NTP does with the system clock. The internal clock adjusts one second in every 100 seconds, to synchronize to the correct time after the NTP daemon is stabilized. Note# #Note: The virtual SGSN-MME sets its internal clock (used by Erlang) based on the clock and accuracy of the compute host. If the compute host has the wrong time compared to the NTP server time, the internal clock cannot correct the time with a large leap, in the same way NTP does with the system clock. The internal clock adjusts one second in every 100 seconds, to synchronize to the correct time after the NTP daemon is stabilized. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
