slot.value: The Erlang clock and the system clock differ more than 1 minute.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: CDRs are not accurate until the clocks are synchronized.

slot.name: action
additionalText
slot.value: Measurement type <name of measurement> has exceeded its threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: A counter or gauge supervised by the performance management function has exceeded its defined alarm threshold. #Note: This is a generic alarm decoupled from the application stepping the counter.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a supervised counter or gauge has exceeded its predefined threshold value. The triggering level is defined by an operator using the #set_pm_sup# CLI command.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The consequence of the alarm depends on the current measurement type.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Proposed solution depends on the actual measurement type, see #Counter Description# and #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the supervised counter or gauge has reached its predefined value for clearing the alarm. The value for clearing the alarm is defined by an operator using the corresponding CLI command.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The threshold for certificate <CertName> expiration has been crossed, and the certificate must be renewed before <validTo> to prevent secure service failure.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The threshold for certificate expiration has been crossed, and the certificate must be renewed to prevent secure service failure.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated only if there is a risk of causing failure of secure service.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: This alarm indicates that a certificate is about to expire and a renewal is needed to prevent secure service failure.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Renew the certificate. #Note: in the case of restricted node credentials, call Ericsson support.Note#

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared by performing renewal for the ENROLLED NodeCredential MO or by removing the users of the MO.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Temperature too high in the unit.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when the PIU monitors too high temperature in the unit. The red Fault LED is lit until the alarm is cleared.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The hwTempHigh alarm is generated if the PIU monitors a temperature that is too high in the unit, due to the environment or a hardware failure. This can occur, for example, when a fan breaks.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If the problem is not solved and temperature continues to rise, the unit will be shut down. Each unit has a local shut down logic, that in case of increased temperature levels shuts down the unit.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Actions to be taken: If a PIU has too high a temperature: -->Check airfilter for dust or other problems. -->Check airflow in and airflow out from the magazine. --> Check that the PFMs are working normal with no alarms. -->Check if the ambient airtemperature is below 45 degree. -->Replace the PIU.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the temperature is within the limits again.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The MME starts an overload protection of DDN throttling for low priority traffic at level 2.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when the MME load has reached its predefined high level threshold value.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the MME load has reached or exceeded the predefined high CPU threshold at level 2.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The MME activates the DDN throttling function for low priority traffic, and requests the SGW to reduce by 95 percent the number of Downlink Data Notification requests for low priority traffic, during a period of DDN throttling.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the MME load is lower than 5 percent below the predefined high CPU threshold at level 2.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The certificate <trustedCertName> is expired or unavailable, risking failure of secure service.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The trusted certificate for the alarming object is expired, or unavailable, risking failure of secure service.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated when no valid trusted certificate is available when a secured service is started.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: This alarm indicates that a secure service failed because of an expired, or non-existing trusted certificate.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Install a valid trusted certificate for the relevant secure service. For more information see Configuring Certificate Management. #Note: in the case of restricted trusted certificates, call Ericsson support.Note#

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared by replacing the TrustedCertificate MO.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when a decreased capacity of one or more fiber links is detected. The link capacity loss may be either partial or full.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The capacity of one or more fiber links is decreased.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The capacity of one or more fiber links is decreased.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check the fiber link capacity by reading the contents of the file /tmp/bcmd_alarms on the SMXB reporting the alarm. Replace the faulty fiber link cable.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the hardware problem is corrected.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the PIU monitors a parity error when reading SlotID. When a parity error is detected the yellow STATUS LED on the reporting PIU is lit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The hwSlotidParityError alarm is generated if the unit monitors a parity error when reading SlotID. A pin is probably broken in the backplane connector, either on the backplane or the PIU itself.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The PIU is not able to reboot and is therefore unable to report a proper ID when sending an alarm.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The problem is probably due to a broken pin in the backplane connector, either on the backplane or the PIU itself. Replace the PIU corresponding to the slot ID. If it still reports parity error, replace the whole magazine (backplane).

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the hardware problem is corrected.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SGSN has lost the connection on the Userplane path = (<Hostname>) <SGSN VIP address>:<SGSN Port number><-><External node address> (Connection between this node and the external node)

slot.name: description
slot.value: The gtpPathFailureUserPlane alarm is generated when a GTP-U path between the SGSN-MME and another node, such as, a GGSN, an RNC or an SGW is down.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when an external node, such as, GGSN or RNC does not respond to a GTP Echo Request message after N3GnS4URequestEcho, N3GpURequestEcho, or N3IuURequestEcho attempts. This can be caused by a node restart or a GTP-C path failure.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Communication is not possible between the SGSN-MME and the node that caused the alarm. If the alarm is caused by a GGSN, the SGSN-MME may initiate a PDP context restoration procedure depending on the configuration of the Gateway Restoration Procedures feature. #Note: There are no consequences for existing PDP contexts resulting from the path failure. Payload is however likely to be unsuccessful, since there is a problem with the path. Note#

slot.name: action
slot.value: See IP-Based Interface Problems in #Troubleshooting# for further information on how to investigate the reason for the failure.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the node responds to a GTP Echo Request message.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The gtpprimeBufferOverflow alarm is generated when the GTP' PDU output buffer has reached its maximum size limit. This due to the billing systems being unavailable or busy. The SGSN starts to write CDRs to a file.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the output buffer has reached its maximum size limit. The reasons for this may be either, or both, of the following: *Busy billing systems;*Unavailable billing systems, that is, a communication error;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The CDRs are stored on files on non-volatile media and will not be transferred as GTP' PDUs. The billing systems have to fetch the files manually over the Gom interface using SFTP or any other appropriate file transfer protocol.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If the alarm is generated due to unavailable billing systems, follow the steps below. Another alarm has already been sent about the communication failure. *Follow the actions to be taken in the alarm #gtpprimeBSFailure#, in order to solve the communication failure.;*Fetch the stored CDR files manually, to the billing system, over the Gom interface using SFTP or any other appropriate file transfer protocol.;If the alarm is generated due to busy billing systems or other external systems beyond the billing systems, follow the steps below. *If this is just a temporary problem, wait until the billing systems is less busy and starts to process CDRs again. If the problem is not temporary or most likely will occur again, upgrade the billing systems or other external systems beyond the billing systems, or both.;*Fetch the stored CDR files manually, to the billing system, over the Gom interface using SFTP or any other appropriate file transfer protocol.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The output buffer usage has decreased below its hysteresis value for alarm clearance.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Ethernet backplane port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> || FSB-<number>:<port> failed to reach maximum capacity.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when an unexpected overload or software fault occurs during startup. This is possibly because of a hardware fault on the SCXB, CMXB, or SMXB hosting the magazine switch.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The Ethernet backplane connections to the PIU cannot run at full speed. This results in reduced capacity and potential loss of critical SGSN-MME internal signaling packets.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
If there are many alarms of this type, there is most likely a problem with the PIU hosting the magazine switch.
If the alarm is not cleared within 30 seconds, restart the SCXB, CMXB, or SMXB using the restart_eqm_element CLI command.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the backplane port has full line speed again. If this does not happen, the SCXB, CMXB, or SMXB indicated by the port number must be restarted to trigger auto-negotiation.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Payload throughput exceeds the license level. Upgrade license!

slot.name: description
slot.value: The admPayloadLicenseExceeded alarm is generated if the traffic exceeds the payload capacity license limit, defined by the number of license steps. The number of license steps required is the sum of the quotients given by dividing the actual GSM payload traffic by 10 kpps and the actual WCDMA Systems payload traffic by 50 kpps.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the payload exceeds the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: None, except abuse written to AdmissionControlUsage log.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Upgrade the payload capacity license. For more information, contact the local Ericsson support.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the payload throughput is reduced below 85% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The DHCP client was unable to start.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is raised when the DHCP client is unable to start.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value:
The DHCP client is unable to start because of the following possible causes:
- The DHCP client is unable to get a host name. - The DHCP client is unable to allocate enough memory for a lease file. - Thread creation failure. - A combination of thread detachment failure and thread cancellation failure.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The corresponding IP interface remains inactive because the DHCP client was unable to start.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Investigate the ringbuf and look for errors with the tag DHCLIENT ERROR.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the DHCP client is started.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Tx output power of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is below low threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the transmitted optical power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is lower than the threshold level. This indicates a fiber or connector problem, or an SFP/SFP+ malfunction.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the Tx output power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is below the low threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check the SFP/SFP+ transceiver, fiber, and connector integrity. Replace the SFP/SFP+ module if it is faulty. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the Tx output power of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: description
slot.value: A manual triggered reload of the SGSN-MME has occurred.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a manual interaction with the system has triggered a reload. The manual interaction may be:*Triggering a node reload;*Activating a new SC;*Restarting all equipments simultaneously;

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: All subscribers in the SGSN-MME are lost. Affected MSs and UEs are not notified. A restart on the permanent or current SC is performed.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is not automatically cleared by the SGSN-MME except after the next node reload, and therefore needs manual clearing by the operator.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Too low voltage on -48V <A or B branch>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated if the PFM monitors too low a voltage on the incoming -48V. No voltage level monitoring is performed on the other PIUs.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: A power supply problem has occurred. The hw48VLow alarm is generated when there is too low voltage on the incoming -48V.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The SGSN-MME will be shut off if the voltage continues to drop on both A and B supply.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Is the voltage below the minimum allowed nominal voltage? Check the site power supply system to see if it reports any problems. Refer to the documentation for that system for more information on fault analysis and replacement of faulty components. If there are no problems with the power supply system, then try and replace the reporting PFM, see #Replacing a Power and Fan Module#. Contact Ericsson support if the problem is not corrected.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the voltage on the incoming -48V is within the limits again.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: A cooperating routing area with identity <MNC-MCC-LAC-RAC> already exists.

slot.name: description
slot.value: If a BSC sends a cell with a RAI already defined as a cooperating routing area in this SGSN, the RAI will be rejected and this alarm will be sent.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The RAI will be rejected, that is, it will not be created as a local RA in this SGSN.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Reconfiguring the SGSN is necessary to avoid that the RAI is both a local routing area and a cooperating routing area. To remove a cooperating RA, use the delete_cooperating_ra CLI command.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm will be cleared when the configuration has been modified and the RAI that was in conflict has been removed from the configuration.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value:
The ss7AlarmStorm alarm is generated in the following situations:
1. When storm of a specific SS7 alarm has been detected in the front-end or back-end process by exceeding the alarm-specific threshold. In this case the alarm that caused the storm is not reported for around 30 seconds.
2. When storm of a specific SS7 alarm has been detected in the SS7 O&M entity by exceeding the alarm-specific threshold. In this case the alarm that caused the storm is deactivated for around 2 minutes.
3. When storm of SS7 alarms and events has been detected in the front-end or back-end process by exceeding the general threshold. Alarms and events covered by alarm and event specific protection respectively are not taken into account. In this case a number of alarms and events from the affected process are discarded until the alarm and event rate decreases. If the alarm is raised with this cause, a clear timer (around 2 minutes) is started.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value:
Depending on the original cause the following consequences are possible: 1. In case of alarm-specific storm detection in the SS7 front-end or back-end process: The affected SS7 alarm from the affected process will not be reported until after around 30 seconds. The affected SS7 alarm from the affected process can be cleared even if the problem reported in the alarm is present.
2. In case of alarm-specific storm detection in the SS7 O&M entity: The affected SS7 alarm from all processes will not be reported until after around 2 minutes. The affected SS7 alarm from all processes will be cleared even if the problem reported in the alarm is present. 3. In case of general alarm storm detection in the SS7 front-end or back-end process a number of SS7 alarms from the affected process are not reported until the alarm rate decreases.

slot.name: action
slot.value: See Actions to Be Taken for the discarded or deactivated SS7 alarm. The SS7 alarm name is stated in the alarm text.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value:
Depending on the original cause the ss7AlarmStorm alarm is cleared in the following cases:
1. In case of alarm-specific storm detection in the SS7 front-end or back-end process: The alarm is cleared after around 30 seconds.
2. In case of alarm-specific storm detection in the SS7 O&M entity: The alarm is cleared after around 2 minutes.
3. In case of general alarm storm detection in the SS7 front-end or back-end process: The alarm is cleared after around 2 minutes.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: There are more than 999 active alarms. No further alarms will be added to the list.

slot.name: description
slot.value: There is a large amount of alarms in the system and these must be dealt with.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value:
This alarm is generated when there is a severe technical problem in the network element.;
The fault management system will no longer try to display all alarms as this consumes processing power, which the system now needs. The alarm is raised when the alarm list contains more than 999 active alarms.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The active alarm list is no longer updated. The log files can, however, still be consulted to get a picture of the current situation.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
Take measures so that at least 50 of the alarms are cleared automatically. (When there are less than 950 alarms in the list, the alarm list will be updated again.);
Alarms are cleared when the fault situation no longer exists. Normally, the alarm software automatically clears the alarm when the fault has been solved. You may clear alarms with the Clear Selected Alarms function if the problem is not relevant, but this should rather be an exception than the rule.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the number of alarms in the alarm list has decreased to below 950.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Signaling link on <number> unavailable for User Part.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The specified link is unavailable for user parts' signaling traffic due to link failure, blocking, or inhibiting. The link is a narrowband signaling link with EqPos, trunk, and time slot.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The signaling link has become unavailable to all signaling traffic due to link failure, blocking, or inhibiting.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The User Part cannot generate traffic for transmission on this link.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
Check the alarm and event log for further details and use the action CLI commands to get more information about the links and remote signaling points.
If there is a failure, the link is restarted by MTP-L3. This is a timer-controlled process that normally makes the link come back into service. If the link does not come back into service, check the physical connections and the hardware. For example, check for broken cables, or oxidized or loose connections.
Traffic carried by the link is transferred to one or more alternative links by means of a changeover procedure. If the problem is not solved, check the SS7 log file, ss7trace.log, for further information.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The signaling link has become available.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Measurement type <name of measurement> has exceeded its threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: A counter or gauge supervised by the performance management function has exceeded its defined alarm threshold. #Note: This is a generic alarm decoupled from the application stepping the counter.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when a supervised counter or gauge has exceeded its predefined threshold value. The triggering level is defined by an operator using the #set_pm_sup# CLI command.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The consequence of the alarm depends on the current measurement type.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Proposed solution depends on the actual measurement type, see #Counter Description# and #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the supervised counter or gauge has reached its predefined value for clearing the alarm. The value for clearing the alarm is defined by an operator using the corresponding CLI command.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The IP path local IP <number> - remote IP <number> has changed its state to INACTIVE. AssocId is <number> EqPos <EqPos>, InstId <number>. UlpKey is <number>: HiWord =<number>, LoWord(Remote SP)=<number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The sctpIPPathFailure alarm is generated when the SCTP detects an IP path failure.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: "This alarm is raised when SCTP has detected an IP path failure. This occurs when DATA chunks cannot be sent over the IP path or when heartbeat statistics show that the path is inactive. The UlpKey (Upper Layer Protocol Key) parameter of the alarm represents the unique value set for an association by the SCTP user. In case of M3UA, it puts RemoteSpId/RemoteSgpId in the low word and the high byte of the high word is NodeID (the low byte of the high word is not used). If the association has only one application server using it, the NodeID value from the associated Routing Key is set in the highest byte. If there are more than one application server using this association, the NodeID byte is filled with 0xFF value. #Note: The #sctpIPPathFailure# alarm is subject to the alarm storm detection. For more information about the alarm storm, see #sctpAlarmStorm#.Note#

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Signaling through this IP path is not possible.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check that the IP-based interfaces are configured correctly. If the IP path is still inactive, check the hardware and physical connections. For further information, see the SS7 log file, ss7trace.log.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: "This alarm is cleared when one of the following conditions is met: 1. SCTP detects that a DATA chunk or heartbeat is transmitted successfully through the IP path. 2. If all available IP paths for an SCTP association are inactive, the association goes down. In this case, all sctpIPPathFailure alarms corresponding to the association are cleared, as they are applicable only within the lifetime of an association. If it is an M3UA association, the #ss7M3uaAssociationDown# alarm is raised. 3. If an inactive IP path is in BLOCKED state after disabling of cross paths usage. Cross paths usage is disabled when the blockCrossPath parameter value is set to 2. Cross paths are also automatically disabled when an SCTP association has more than 16 IP paths and the blockCrossPath parameter value is set to 1." 4. After an NCB failover, the sctpIpPathFailure alarm is cleared. Use the #sctp_status# or the #ss7_status# CLI command to check if the SCTP paths are still inactive.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The automatic export of the <managerId> backup <backupName> failed due to the following reason: <reason>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is raised when the automatic export of an automatic or manual configuration backup fails. The reason for the failure needs to be investigated.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The export of future configuration backups could fail if the problems causing the failure remain unsolved.

slot.name: action
slot.value: For information on import and export problems when using a remote SFTP server, see #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
additionalText
slot.value: At least one TA received in an NG Setup Request from gNodeB <gNodeB_Id> in PLMN <MCC-MNC> <with gNodeB name gNodeB_Name> is not configured in the AMF.

slot.name: description
slot.value: At least one TA received in an NG Setup Request from the gNodeB is not configured in the AMF.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The AMF will return an NG Setup Failure to the gNodeB.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check that TA configurations are consistent between the gNodeB side and the AMF side. All nwcGnodeBTaiMismatch alarms that are older than 24 hours will be cleared. To force clearing of alarms before 24 hours have elapsed, use the clear_alarms CLI command. For more information regarding handling of disconnected gNodeBs, see #N2 Interface Description#.

slot.name: causeClear
description
causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: All SS7 traffic is rerouted through the remaining SS7 devices. The maximum SS7 performance will decrease, which could lead to overload on the remaining SS7 devices.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the SS7 device on this PIU or VM becomes operational.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Internally measured supply voltage of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is below low threshold.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the internally measured supply voltage of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is lower than the threshold level. This indicates an SFP/SFP+ malfunction or an SMXB port problem.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the supply voltage of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is below the low threshold level.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check if other SFP/SFP+ transceivers in the same SMXB also report #transceiverVoltageLow# alarms. In this case, replace the SXMB. For more information, see #Replacing an SMXB#. If the alarm is raised on the particular SFP/SFP+ transceiver, replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the internally measured supply voltage of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver is back to the allowed range.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The BGws could not be contacted.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated for the push delivery mechanism, when neither the primary nor the secondary Ericsson BGws are operational, or when the primary BGw is not operational and a secondary BGw is not specified.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The BGws cannot be contacted. This alarm is generated when there is a failure in the network link as a result of hardware failure.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The log files cannot be transferred to the BGws.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Use one or all of the following actions to prevent future alarms of this type: *Repair or replace the network link or use a bypass network link.;*Restart or repair the BGw.;*Specify another primary or another secondary BGw IP address to secure the delivery of the log files if both the primary and the secondary BGw are not working.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: When the server has gone ready for the pull-function. Also when an rpc-call to the primary bgw was ok, and similar when an rpc-call to the primary bgw was wrong but to the second bgw was ok.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: -48V <A or B branch> is lost on the PFM.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when the PFM monitors no voltage on the incoming -48V that supplies the PFM. The same voltage monitoring is performed on the other PIUs, but will be reported as hw48VLost. The green LED is off.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: A power supply problem has occurred. Alarm text "-48V A is lost on the PFM" indicates that the PFM has no primary power supply from the front cables. Alarm text "-48V B is lost on the PFM" indicates that the PFM has no secondary power supply from the backplane, and that this is probably due to a problem with the primary power supply to the other PFM.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: One power supply is lost. If the other supply is lost too, the unit will shut down.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If only one PFM reports the problem, there is an internal power problem on the PFM. Replace the faulty PFM, see Replacing a Power and Fan Module. If both the PFMs and some other PIUs in the same magazine are reporting the problem, there is a power supply problem, one of the -48V branches is missing. Check -48V LEDs on the PFMs and fuses on the external power supply system. If both the PFMs and all other PIUs in the same magazine reports the problem, the external power supply A or B is missing. Check the power supply system to see if it reports any problems.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is automatically cleared when voltage is available again, for example, when the faulty PFM is replaced.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the PIU monitors a parity error when reading MagID. When a parity error is detected the yellow STATUS LED on the reporting PIU is lit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The hwMagidParityError alarm is generated if the unit monitors a parity error when reading MagID. There is probably an incorrect DIP switch configuration of an address plug.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The PIU is not able to identify the magazine and is therefore unable to report a proper ID when sending an alarm.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The problem is probably due to an incorrect DIP switch configuration of an address plug. Check the address plugs and correct any faulty DIP switch configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the hardware problem is corrected.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of IP Sessions on the node has reached the licensed capacity.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of IP Sessions in the SGSN-MME reaches the purchased capacity limit and the license enforces a hard limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when total number of IP Sessions has reached the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Attempts to create IP Sessions are rejected as long as the number of IP Sessions is equal to the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for the number of IP Sessions or change network configuration.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of IP Sessions is reduced below 95% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Payload throughput is approaching the license level.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The admPayloadLicenseReached alarm is generated if the traffic approaches the payload capacity license limit, defined by the number of license steps. The number of license steps required is the sum of the quotients given by dividing the actual GSM payload traffic by 10 kpps and the actual WCDMA Systems payload traffic by 50 kpps.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the payload has reached 85% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the payload throughput is reduced below 70% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Charging log files have exceeded maximum file age.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the charging log files remain in the target directory longer than the maximum file age specified by the #set_chs_config# CLI command. The log files are therefore not transferred to the external billing system on time, which could result in data loss because of wrapping. Wrapping is when one file has been filled, and the application starts writing log data to the log file with the next sequence number, overwriting any possible previous version of the file. When the file with the highest number has been filled, the application opens the file with sequence number 1 again. Wrapping is only applicable if the number of log files is set to 2 or more by using the #set_log_config# CLI command. This alarm is not generated for empty log files in the target directory.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when: *The maximum age of the log files is set too low.;*The delivery mechanism is not working. For the push delivery mechanism, this could be because the log's file age period is too long or the push size (%) is too big.; All these settings are configurable by using the #set_chs_config# CLI command.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The log files are not transferred to the external billing system on time, which could result in data loss when wrapping.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: No charging log files have exceeded maximum file age.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> is not supported.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the SFP/SFP+ transceiver type cannot be identified. This indicates a hardware fault or the use of an unsupported transceiver.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: Traffic loss on the Ethernet port.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Verify that the newly installed SFP/SFP+ transceiver is of supported type. See #MkX Components and Spare Parts# for a list of approved SFP/SFP+ transceivers. Replace the SFP/SFP+ transceiver. For more information, see #Replacing an SFP Module#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the unsupported or faulty SFP/SFP+ transceiver is removed from the cage.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Remote SP is unavailable for User Part traffic. RemoteSpId <number>. LocalSpId <number>. RC <number>. SctpEndPointNo <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: Remote Signaling Process is unavailable for user part traffic.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated if the remote Signaling Process is unavailable for User Part traffic. If the remote Signaling Process was not deactivated by management order, M3UA will try to activate the remote Signaling Process.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The User Part cannot generate traffic for transmission to the unavailable remote Signaling Process. Traffic carried by the remote Signaling Process is transferred to one or several alternative remote Signaling Processes.

slot.name: action
slot.value: If there is a failure, the remote Signaling Process is restarted by M3UA. This is a timer-controlled process and the remote Signaling Process should come back in service. In the case that the remote Signaling Process does not come back in service, the physical connections and hardware should be checked. Check the SS7 log file for further details.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the remote Signaling Process is available again.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: SDS GW <SDS GW ID> cannot be reached.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the MME cannot reach an SDS GW over the SGs-Lite interface on the configured IP address(es). #Note:This alarm is related to a restricted feature and not for general use.Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the last TCP connection towards an SDS GW is disconnected or when the MME fails to create the first TCP connection towards an SDS GW after all allowed re-attempts.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If the most preferred SDS GW is unreachable, the MME selects the next most preferred SDS GW (if available) that has the number of established TCP connections not less than the minimum TCP connections parameter value.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when any of the TCP connections between the MME and the SDS GW is reestablished or the SDS GW data is deleted from the MME.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Application <application name> encountered a serious problem. Details: <details>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: A critical error has occurred in an O&M application during startup caused by an upgrade, a restart, or a failover. Automatically triggered restarts have not solved the problem.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The consequences depend on the actual error condition. The application name shown in the alarm text can indicate which O&M application is not working.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
If the Certificate Management triggers the alarm and the error code is 10016 (Device busy), clear the pending configuration on the FSB: - Logon to the primary FSB. - Commit or cancel the pending configuration by using the #commit# or #rollback# CLI command. For more information, see OS Configuration Framwork (CLI). - Clear the alarm by triggering an NCB failover using the #get_active_ncb# and #restart_eqm_element# CLI commands. For more information, see Plug-In Unit (CLI). Contact Ericsson support if the problem is not corrected.
If Certificate Management triggers the alarm with another error code, or the error code is missing: - Logon to the primary FSB. - Perform an FSB switchover using the #reboot# CLI command. For more information, see GSN Support Application (CLI). - Clear the alarm by triggering an NCB failover using the #get_active_ncb# and #restart_eqm_element# CLI commands. For more information, see Plug-In Unit (CLI). Contact Ericsson support if the problem is not corrected.
If another O&M application triggers the alarm: - If disk problems are indicated by other alarms, correct the disk problems first before proceeding. - Clear the alarm by triggering an NCB failover using the #get_active_ncb# and #restart_eqm_element# CLI commands. For more information, see Plug-In Unit (CLI). If the alarm persists, restart the SGSN-MME by using the #node_restart# CLI command with root privileges. For more information, see Application Restart (CLI). If the alarm persists, perform a fallback to a previous software configuration using the #manualSetSC# CLI command with root privileges. For more information, see Software Configuration (CLI). #Note: root privileges are gained by using the sudo OS command. Defining sudo rules for a user account allows this user account to use sudo. For information about how to define sudo rules, see #Operator Access Handling#.Note# Contact Ericsson support if the problem is not corrected.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is automatically cleared when the SGSN-MME is restarted and the error condition has disappeared.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The local processor has lost its processing power for the signaling link on <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The local end of the signaling link is unavailable since the back-end has lost contact with the front-end. The link is a narrowband signaling link with EqPos, trunk, and time slot.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated if the local processor handling the link is lost. The back end has lost contact with the front end handling the link.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The link is unavailable and cannot handle any network traffic.

slot.name: action
slot.value: The MTP-L3 module automatically starts a timer T1. If this timer expires before the Local Processor Outage has recovered, the traffic is automatically diverted to an alternative link and the link is realigned.;If this alarm occurs frequently, the load on the links is to be reduced by either adding additional links.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Capabilities of SFP/SFP+ transceiver at Ethernet port <magazine.slot.2.1>:<port> mismatch with port configuration.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the Ethernet port parameters do not match the capabilities of the SFP/SFP+ transceiver installed on the Ethernet port. This alarm is triggered when the Ethernet port is configured with 10 Gbps line speed while the installed SFP/SFP+ transceiver supports 1Gbps or opposite.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the configured line speed or duplex mode does not correspond to the capabilities of the installed SFP/SFP+ transceiver.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The Ethernet speed and throughput may be reduced.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Modify the Ethernet port configuration to match the capabilities of the installed transceiver.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the configured line speed or duplex mode matches the installed transceiver capabilities.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: < Number of bad nodes > bad node internal network paths detected from alarm originator.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: Several PIUs cannot be reached on one of the backplane right-side Ethernet networks.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is automatically cleared when the network problem is gone/corrected, for example, when the faulty PIU is replaced.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Route Set unavailable to destination <point code>. Affected NodeID is <number>, with Local SPC <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: No signaling route is available to the specified destination. For ITU and TTC standards, the SPC value is printed in the format: 0-16383 and 0-65535 respectively. For ANSI and China standards, the SPC value is printed in the format: 0-16777215 ([0-255]-[0-255]-[0-255]).

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This fault condition occurs if no signaling route is available for traffic to a particular destination.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Due to the unavailability of the route set, no messages to or from the destination can be sent or received.

slot.name: action
slot.value: **If there is a failure, the links are restarted by MTP-L3, or associations for M3UA, whichever is applicable. This is a timer-controlled process and a route within the route set should become available again.;**In the event of the route set not becoming available, the physical connections and hardware is to be checked.;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when a signaling route becomes available for traffic to a particular destination

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The association to the CBC with the IP address(es) <IP address(es)> and the port number <port number> is lost. <SCTP cause is [corresponding cause] Origin is [local user_remote user].>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is generated when the SCTP association between the MME and the CBC is lost. The alarm displays the IP address(es), the port number, the SCTP cause, and the source that triggers the alarm.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The SCTP association is lost due to either network failure, CBC restart, SCTP device failure, configuration problems, or timing problems. For common causes displayed due to association loss, see #diameterConnectionDown#.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The MME cannot receive the warning messages from the CBC, resulting in a failure to send the warning messages to the end user. For more information, see #Public Warning System#.

slot.name: action
slot.value: To resolve the displayed SCTP cause, see SCTP-Based Interface Problems in #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the SCTP association between the MME and the CBC is re-established or when the CBC is removed using the #action_mme_delete_cbc# CLI command. For more information on the CLI command, see #SBc Interface (CLI)#.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: No ELIM2 license key file installed.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The admNoLicenseKeyFileInstalled alarm is generated if no valid ELIM2 license-key file is installed in the SGSN-MME.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: No ELIM2 license-key file has ever been installed in this system.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The SGSN-MME is in operational state integration unlock.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when a license key file is sucessfully loaded.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Loss of frame is detected on PCM trunk <Trunk>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the interface has lost the frame on E1/T1 level.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the incoming data stream is not synchronized with the clocking of the PIU. The signalling link may not be out of service.

slot.name: action
description
causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated if an FSB disk is faulty.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value:
An FSB switchover will be triggered to the secondary FSB if the disk fault is on the primary FSB. A node restart will be triggered if no secondary FSB exists and an FSB switchover is not possible. The faulty FSB will try to repair itself by re-installing and re-mirroring itself against the primary FSB.
If the disk fault is on the secondary FSB, the faulty FSB will try to repair itself by re-installing and re-mirroring itself against the primary FSB.
The SGSN-MME will be running without an redundant FSB until a working and synchronized secondary FSB exist.
If there is a disk write fault, the SGSN-MME might be running without a properly working redundant FSB.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
When a hard disk error occurs, the faulty FSB tries to repair itself by re-installing and re-mirroring itself, thus the failing FSB becomes the secondary FSB.
Inspect the alarm text, which explains the cause of the fault:
a. If the fault is a write fault, replace the secondary FSB (the FSB that failed) immediately. See #Replacing an FSB#.
b. If the fault is a read fault, an automatic repair of the hard disk is performed by re-installing or re-mirroring the FSB. The board reboots and becomes unavailable each time the alarm is set and becomes available again when the alarm is cleared. If this pattern is seen after several days of operation, replace the FSB immediately and send it to the factory for repair. See #Replacing an FSB#.
c. If the fault is a timeout fault, the FSB will be halted. Contact Ericsson support before replacing a faulty FSB. For instructions on how to replace an FSB, see #Replacing an FSB#.
For Virtual: This alarm indicates the existence of some problems with access to the disk on the faulty FSB. This problem can be caused by connectivity problems, read or write errors in the Cloud HW. To locate the root cause for this alarm, take the following actions in the Cloud HW: *Check the connection to the disk in the Cloud related to the faulty FSB; *Check the I/O errors on the disk in the Cloud related to the faulty FSB;

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is automatically cleared when the FSB is started, either after the faulty FSB has succeeded with an automatically repair or a successful FSB replacement has been made.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Time Sync: NTP not synchronized with external server. Local Server used.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The NTP daemon (xntpd) on the NCB requires a clear UDP connection on port 123 with at least one specified host. The existing hosts can be displayed using the #list_ntp_server# or #list_ntp_ipv6server# CLI command. The alarm is generated when no NTP server is configured and the default configuration is used. In this case, the NCB NTP daemon is configured to run without external synchronization. #Note: After a restart, it may take several minutes before the NTP daemon has stabilized and the alarm is cleared. Note# #Note: If the physical SGSN-MME have been powered off or been powerless for more than 10 minutes, will the internal clock (used by Erlang) initiate with a start time that is not possible to correct with large leap, like NTP does with the system clock. It will take 1 seconds per 100 seconds to synchronize to a correct time after the NTP daemon has stabilized. Note# #Note: The virtual SGSN-MME will set its internal clock (used by Erlang) based on the clock and accuracy of the compute host. If the compute host has wrong time compared to the NTP server time, the internal clock is not possible to correct with large leap, like NTP does with the system clock. It will take 1 seconds per 100 seconds to synchronize to a correct time after the NTP daemon has stabilized. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated by a transmission error on the remote node.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Node will fail to maintain synchronized time externally. Internally the node will be synchronized with respect absolute time (UTC).

slot.name: action
slot.value: Investigate the reason why NTP cannot reach the external hosts that have been configured. If necessary, create new host names or IP addresses using the CLI command #create_ntp_server#. The NTP synchronization status may be checked using CLI command #show_ntp_status# on NCB console.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The NTP daemon (xntpd) on NCB has reestablished a clear UDP connection on port 123 with at least one of the hosts specified in the NTP configuration. #Note: After a restart or failover, it may take several minutes before the NTP daemon has stabilized and the alarm is cleared. Note#

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Diameter Connection to peer <DiameterPeerNumber> with IP address <Ipv4v6Address> is down due to problem on <Diameter_SCTP> level. Cause: <corresponding cause code> Origin is <Local user_Remote user>.

slot.name: description
slot.value:
The alarm diameterConnectionDown is raised when an initial attempt to establish a connection using all the configured IP address(es) of a Diameter peer is unsuccessful.
If an existing connection, using an IP address, of a Diameter-based interface fails, an attempt to re-establish the connection is made using the same IP address . If this attempt fails and if there is a secondary IP address configured to the Diameter peer, an attempt to establish a connection using the secondary IP address is made. If that attempt fails as well, the alarm is raised.
On Diameter level, the cause is "No CEA successfully received". On the SCTP level, a number of cause codes are available.
The alarm always displays the primary IP address.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value:
Diameter connection is down because of problem on: a) The Diameter level (available cause code): "No CEA successfully received."
b) The SCTP level; SCTP connection could not be (re)-established, (available cause codes): 1:Initiation Failure, max INIT retransmits reached. 2:Shutdown Failure, max SHUTDOWN retransmits reached. 3:ULP Requested Terminate. 4:Undetermined Error. 5:Peer Requested Abort. 6:Max Retransmits Failed, no peers responding. 7:Inbound Streams Not Opened. 8:Outbound Streams Not Opened. 9:Resource Error, local resources. 10:Invalid INIT ACK. 11:Peer Requested Terminate. 12:No User Data In Chunk. 13:Data reassembly error. 14:Wrong Stream Sequence Number. 15:Invalid Sack Chunk. 16:Stale Cookie Error. 17:Local Requested Abort. 18:Invalid stream Id has been detected. 19:Mandatory parameter is missing. 20:Address can not be resolved. 21:Mandatory parameter is invalid. 22:Association has been restarted with new IP addresses. 23:Serious protocol violation has been detected. 205:ICMP message received and treated as ABORT chunk. 210:INIT ACK was received with DNS Host Name, but DNS Host Names are not supported.
Received cause codes other than the ones specified are displayed as a number only. If there is no cause code available, the displayed text is: "No cause code available."

slot.name: consequence
slot.value:
For Diameter cause codes: Signaling over the Diameter connection is impossible. For SCTP cause codes 1, 7-10 and 16: SCTP association could not be established. For SCTP cause codes 3-6, 11-15 and 17: SCTP association was terminated.
Also, SCTP association failures will make signaling over a Diameter connection impossible.

slot.name: action
slot.value:
For Diameter cause codes: See relevant Diameter-based interface chapter in #Troubleshooting# for further information on how to investigate the reason for the failure.
For SCTP cause codes 1 and 3-17: See SCTP-based interface problems in #Troubleshooting# for further information on how to investigate the reason for the failure.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: CEA is received successfully. The alarm is cleared when: - Communication to remote peer is ok on Diameter level and a Diameter CEA is successfully received. - The peer is deleted from configuration data by the operator. - A cause is detected that is different compared to an existing instance of the alarm. A new instance of the alarm is raised.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The file system on <disk partition> is full.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the disk space usage exceeds a certain threshold level for any one of the following file systems: */tmp, /Core, /logs and /mnt/local file systems respectively.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The alarm is generated by storage capacity problems. The alarm is raised when the disk space usage of the selected disk has exceeded the pre-defined threshold of 90%.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The disk will work properly for a while after the alarm was sent. If no action is taken to relieve the overload of the disk within that period of time, the disk may be full.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Remove files that are superfluous, or not in use, on the corresponding disks.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the disk space usage of the selected disk has decreased below 85%.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The automatic export of the <managerId> backup <backupName> failed due to the following reason: <reason>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The alarm is raised when the automatic export of a scheduled backup fails. The reason for the failure needs to be investigated.; If the alarm is raised after a node restart when the system local scheduled backup is missing from the local storage then the alarm does not indicate an issue. The alarm can be ignored and cleared.

slot.name: causeRaise
consequence
slot.value: The export of future scheduled backups could fail if the problems causing the failure remain unsolved.

slot.name: action
slot.value: For information on import and export problems when using a remote SFTP server, see #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: causeClear
action
slot.value: Use the #activate_config_pending# or #undo_config_pending# CLI commands. For the OSS-RC, the ENM, or a third-party OSS, use the commit or discard-changes NETCONF operations.

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The pending configuration is activated or undone.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm indicates that configuration has been pending for at least 4 hours.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when configuration has been pending for at least 4 hours.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The existing pending configuration prevents the OSS-RC, the ENM, or a third-party OSS from performing configuration changes. The pending configuration may also mislead other users during configuration or consistency checking.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: The total number of simultaneously attached users on the node is approaching the licensed capacity.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This alarm is generated when the total number of SAU in the GSN is approaching the purchased capacity limit.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This alarm is generated when when the total number of SAU exceeds 80% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: None. However if the number of SAU continues to rise it may reach the licensed capacity limit of the node.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Extend the license for number of SAU or change network configuration

slot.name: causeClear
slot.value: The alarm is cleared when the total number of SAU is reduced below 70% of the licensed capacity limit.

slot.name: area
slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: There is no redundant file server available and in synch.

slot.name: description
causeRaise
slot.value: There is no redundant file server available or FSBs are not in sync.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: No redundant file server is available.

slot.name: action
causeClear
slot.value: This alarm is cleared when the secondary FSB is available and synchronized.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: Remote SPC <number> available. Affected NodeID is <number>, with Local SPC <number>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: Remote SPC is available. This event is only relevant at start-up. For ITU and TTC standards, the SPC value is printed in the format: 0-16383 and 0-65535 respectively. For ANSI and China standards, the SPC value is printed in the format: 0-16777215 ([0-255]-[0-255]-[0-255]).

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The previously inaccessible remote SP is now accessible.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The status of the recovered SP is marked as "allowed" and traffic can be sent to the remote node. A local broadcast, SP accessible, is initiated by sending N_STATE_ind primitive, User in Service, with SSN 1 to the SCCP users. The subsystem status test is initiated for all subsystems located at the recovered node.

slot.name: description
slot.value: This event is generated when a restart escalation has been ordered due to too frequent connection restarts.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Too frequent connection restarts have occurred on this AP.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: A small local restart will be triggered.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Relevant logs should be made available to Ericsson for analysis. For more information about what logs to collect, see #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: <First occasion within configured period [time-period] hours when all PGWs are 'temporarily unavailable'. Affected APN is [APN] OR First occasion within configured period [time-period] hours when all PGWs are 'blocked'. Affected APN is [APN] OR First occasion within configured period [time-period] hours when all PGWs are under the combination of 'temporary unavailable' and 'blocked'. Affected APN is [APN]>

slot.name: description
slot.value: The event is generated when all PGWs that serve the APN are marked as "blocked" or "temporarily unavailable" at the PGW selection, and is the first event during the event notification period. The event notification period is specified by the GwEventNotificationPeriod parameter.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The event is generated when all PGWs that serve the APN are marked as "blocked" or "temporarily unavailable" at the PGW selection, and is the first event during the configured period.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: Only the first pgwAllBlockedperApn event is generated at the PGW selection within the configured period.

slot.name: action
slot.value: For PGWs in the "temporarily unavailable" status, check the connectivity of the backbone network and make sure these PGWs are working properly. For PGWs in the "blocked" status, check if all of these PGWs can be set as "available".

slot.name: description
slot.value: S.M.A.R.T. status check returned "DISK OK" but found prefail attribute value(s) <= threshold.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check S.M.A.R.T. log. See #Troubleshooting# for further information.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: SCTP SendFailure notification was received for AssocId: <AssocId> Ulp: <Ulp> remote IP address(es): <RemoteIPs> port: <Port> with ReturnCode: <ReturnCode>. Failed to send <SendFailedCnt> packets.

slot.name: description
slot.value: If a message cannot be delivered, SCTP shall invoke sctpSendFailure notification on the ULP. RFC 2960.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: SCTP SendFailure notification is received from SS7 SCTP.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: An AP take over has failed (EquipmentID=<EquipmentID>).

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The event is generated when an AP takeover fails to recover subscribers.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: A failure during AP takeover result in lost subscribers on the affected AP.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Relevant logs should be made available to Ericsson for analysis. For more information about what logs to collect, see #Troubleshooting#.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: TA <TAName> changed RAT type from <RATType1> to <RATType2>.

slot.name: description
slot.value: The epsTaRatTypeChanged event is generated if the eNodeB changes the RAT type for a TA from LTE to NB-IoT, or the opposite. For more information, see #Massive IoT#.

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: The eNodeB sends an S1 Setup Request or eNB Configuration Update, where the RAT type has changed for a TA. A change of the RAT type for a TA can be caused by misconfiguring the RAT type of an eNodeB. In this scenario, an eNodeB is configured with a wrong and different RAT type than that of the other eNodeBs serving the same TA. Then the wrong RAT type is updated for the TA.

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: If the eNodeB reconfigures a TA and changes RAT type for the TA, the UE remains in the TA when the eNodeB changes RAT type. When the UE performs the next intra-TAU, if the RAT type in the current TA and the RAT type in the new TA are different, the UE is detached because UEs are not allowed to change RAT type during intra-TAU. If a TA is updated with a wrong RAT type by a misconfigured eNodeB, the UEs in the TA can get a wrong access type. After the UEs perform a mobility procedure, they get a wrong access type, which is caused by the wrong RAT type of the TA.

slot.name: action
slot.value: Check and make sure that all eNodeBs in the TA are configured with the correct RAT type.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: An updated GTPv2 restart counter is received on the gtpv2-c path = <SGSN-MME VIP address> (SGSN-MME) - <SGW VIP address> (SGW).

slot.name: description
slot.value: This event is generated after an SGW has restarted and the SGW notifies the SGSN-MME of the restart. #Note: This happens for LTE access type if the feature gw_failure_restoration_lte is activated. This also happens for the S4-SGSN of the WCDMA access type if the gw_failure_restoration_wcdma is activated. Note#

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: This event is generated when the SGW notifies the SGSN-MME of a restart of SGW through updating the restart counter. #Note: This happens for LTE access type if the feature gw_failure_restoration_lte is activated. This also happens for the S4-SGSN of the WCDMA access type if the gw_failure_restoration_wcdma is activated. Note#

slot.name: consequence
slot.value: The SGSN-MME deletes or restores all the PDN connections related to the restarted SGW.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: A restart in the MSC/VLR with VLR name <VlrName>, locally configured as <MscVlrName>, has taken place.

slot.value: This event is generated when a restart in the MSC/VLR has taken place.

slot.name: consequence

slot.name: description
slot.value: The admFeatureLicenseChanged event is generated if a licensed feature is enabled or disabled.

slot.value: SW Load Check and License Mgmt

slot.name: causeRaise
slot.value: Disk has already failed according to S.M.A.R.T. or S.M.A.R.T. predicts failure within 24 hours.

slot.name: additionalText
slot.value: All UE-associated logical N2 connections from gNodeB <gNodeB_Id> in PLMN <MCC-MNC> <with gNodeB name gNodeB_Name> have been removed.
